sentence: Funspot, the world's largest video arcade (now called museum), is located in Laconia.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire personalities include founding father Nicholas Gilman, Senator Daniel Webster, revolutionary war hero John Stark, editor-in-chief Horace Greeley, founder of Christian science religion Mary Baker Eddy, poet Robert Frost, astronaut Alan Shepard, rock musician Ronnie James Dio, author Dan Brown, actor Adam Sandler, inventor Dean Kamen, actors Sarah Silverman and Seth Meyers, restorers Richard and Maurice McDonald, and President Franklin Pierce of the United States.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey is a state in the northeastern United States of America.

name: new_jersey
sentence: It is bordered to the north and east by New York State; to the east, south-east and south by the Atlantic Ocean; to the west by Delaware River and Pennsylvania; and to the southwest by Delaware Bay and Delaware State.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey is the fourth smallest state by region, but the 11th most populous, with 8,882,190 inhabitants in 2019 and an area of 8,722.58 square miles, making it the most populous of the 50 U.S. states.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The capital is Trenton, while the biggest city is Newark.

name: new_jersey
sentence: All but one of the counties in New Jersey are in the combined statistical zones of New York City or Philadelphia; therefore, the largest metropolitan area of the state is in Greater New York.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey was first inhabited by Amerindians for at least 2,800 years, the Lenape being the dominant group at the time of the arrival of Europeans in the early 17th century.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Dutch and Swedish settlers founded the first European colonies in the state.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The British then took control of the area, naming it Province of New Jersey – after the largest of the Channel Islands, Jersey – and granting it as a colony to Sir George Carteret and John Berkeley, 1st Baron Berkeley of Stratton.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey was the scene of several important battles during the American Revolutionary War.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In the 19th century, the factories of the six major cities of Camden, Paterson, Newark, Trenton, Jersey City and Elizabeth contributed to the country's industrial revolution.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The central location of New Jersey in the northeast megalopolis fuelled its rapid growth and suburbanization in the second half of the 20th century.

name: new_jersey
sentence: At the turn of the twenty-first century, the state's economy became increasingly diverse, while its multicultural population began to return to more urban environments within the state, thus exceeding the growth of the suburbs since 2008.

name: new_jersey
sentence: By 2020, New Jersey had the largest number of millionaires per capita in all US states, with 9.76% of households — more than 323,000 out of 3.3 million in the state as a whole — meeting the criteria.

name: new_jersey
sentence: According to 2017 data, it was the second poorest U.S. state with median household income.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey's public education system is consistently ranked among or among the 50 U.S. states.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Approximately 180 million years ago, during the Jurassic period, New Jersey bordered North Africa.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The pressure of the North American-African collision gave rise to the Appalachians.

name: new_jersey
sentence: About 18,000 years ago, the ice age gave rise to glaciers that reached New Jersey.

name: new_jersey
sentence: As the glaciers retreated, they left Lake Passaic behind, as well as many rivers, swamps and gorges.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey was originally established by Amerindians, with Lenni-Lenape dominant at the time of contact.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Scheyichbi is the name of Lenape for the land that is now New Jersey.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Lenapes were several self-governing groups engaged in maize farming to complete their hunting and harvesting in the area surrounding the Delaware River, the lower Hudson River and the western Long Island Strait.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Lenape was divided into matrilineal clans that were based on common female ancestors.

name: new_jersey
sentence: These clans were organized into three distinct phratries identified by their animal sign: Turtle, Turkey, and Wolf.

name: new_jersey
sentence: They first met the Dutch at the beginning of the seventeenth century, and their main relationship with Europeans was the fur trade.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Dutch became the first European to claim land in New Jersey.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Dutch colony of New Netherlands consisted of parts of modern states of the Middle Atlantic.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Although the European principle of land ownership was not recognized by the Lenape, Dutch West India Company policy required its settlers to purchase the land they settled.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The first to do so was Michiel Pauw, who established a patroness named Pavonia in 1630 along the northern river, which eventually became Bergen.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Peter Minuit's acquisition of land along the Delaware River established the colony of New Sweden.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The entire region became a territory of England on 24 June 1664, after an English fleet under the command of Colonel Richard Nicolls sailed in what is now New York Harbor and took control of Fort Amsterdam, annexing the entire province.

name: new_jersey
sentence: During the English Civil War, Channel Island of Jersey remained faithful to the British Crown and gave refuge to the king.

name: new_jersey
sentence: It was from the royal square of Saint-Hélier that Charles II of England was declared king in 1649, after the execution of his father, Charles I.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The North American lands were divided by Charles II, who gave his brother, the Duke of York (later King James II), the region between New England and Maryland as an exclusive colony (as opposed to a royal colony).

name: new_jersey
sentence: James then granted land between the Hudson River and the Delaware River (the land that would become New Jersey) to two friends who had remained faithful during the English Civil War: Sir George Carteret and Lord Berkeley of Stratton.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The region was called the Province of New Jersey.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Since the establishment of the state, New Jersey has been characterized by ethnic and religious diversity.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Congregationalists from New England settle alongside Scottish Presbyterians and Dutch Reformed Migrants.

name: new_jersey
sentence: While the majority of residents lived in cities with 100-acre (40 ha) individual lands, some wealthy owners owned large properties.

name: new_jersey
sentence: English Quakers and Anglicans owned large land properties.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Unlike the Plymouth, Jamestown, and other colonies, New Jersey was populated by a second wave of immigrants from other colonies instead of those who migrated directly from Europe.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey remained agrarian and rural throughout the colonial era, and commercial agriculture developed sporadically.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Some townships, such as Burlington on the Delaware River and Perth Amboy, have emerged as important ports for the expedition to New York and Philadelphia.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The fertile land of the colony and tolerant religious policy attracted more settlers, and the population of New Jersey increased to 120,000 in 1775.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Colonization during the first 10 years of British domination took place along the Hackensack River and Arthur Kill-settlers came mainly from New York and New England.

name: new_jersey
sentence: On 18 March 1673 Berkeley sold half of the colony to Quakers, England, which established the Delaware Valley region as a Quaker colony.

name: new_jersey
sentence: (William Penn acted for some time as trustee for the lands.)

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey was governed very briefly as two distinct provinces, east and west of Jersey, for 28 years between 1674 and 1702, sometimes part of New York or the Dominion of New England.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In 1702 the two provinces were brought together under the direction of a royal governor, rather than an exclusive province.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Edward Hyde, Lord Cornbury, became the colony's first governor as a royal colony.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Britain believed that he was an ineffective and corrupt sovereign, taking bribes and speculating on earth.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In 1708, he was recalled to England.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey was then governed by the governors of New York, but this overturned the settlers of New Jersey, who accused these governors of favouritism in New York.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Judge Lewis Morris led the case for a separate governor, and was appointed governor by King George II in 1738.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey was one of the Thirteen Colonies that rebelled against British rule in the American Revolution.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Constitution of New Jersey of 1776 was adopted on July 2, 1776, just two days before the Second Continental Congress declared Britain's American independence.

name: new_jersey
sentence: It is an Act of the Provincial Congress, which has become the legislative body of the State.

name: new_jersey
sentence: To reassure the neutrals, she predicted that it would become null if New Jersey achieved reconciliation with Britain.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Richard Stockton, John Witherspoon, Francis Hopkinson, John Hart and Abraham Clark were among those who signed the United States Declaration of Independence on July 4, 1776.

name: new_jersey
sentence: During the American Revolutionary War, the British and American armies crossed New Jersey many times, and several crucial battles took place in the state.

name: new_jersey
sentence: As a result, today's New Jersey is often called "The Cross of the American Revolution."

name: new_jersey
sentence: The winter quarters of the Continental Army were established twice by General George Washington in Morristown, which was called "The Military Capital of the American Revolution".

name: new_jersey
sentence: On the night of December 25-26, 1776, the Mainland Army under George Washington crossed the Delaware River.

name: new_jersey
sentence: After the crossing, he surprised and defeated the Hessian troops at the Battle of Trenton.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Just over a week after the victory in Trenton, the U.S. forces won a major victory by stopping General Cornwallis' charges at the second Battle of Trenton.

name: new_jersey
sentence: By escaping from Cornwallis' army, Washington made a surprise attack on Princeton and successfully defeated British forces there on 3 Jan. 1777.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The painting by Emanuel Leutze from Washington Crossing the Delaware became an icon of the Revolution.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The American forces under Washington met forces under General Henry Clinton in the Battle of Monmouth during an undecided engagement in June 1778.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Washington attempted to take the British column by surprise; when the British army tried to flank the Americans, the Americans withdrew into disorder.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The ranks were then reorganized and resisted the British accusations.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In the summer of 1783, the Continental Congress met at Nassau Hall at Princeton University, making Princeton the capital of the country for four months.

name: new_jersey
sentence: It was there that the Continental Congress learned the signing of the Treaty of Paris (1783), which ended the war.

name: new_jersey
sentence: On December 18, 1787, New Jersey became the third state to ratify the United States Constitution, which was very popular in New Jersey, as it prevented New York and Pennsylvania from imposing tariffs on goods imported from Europe.

name: new_jersey
sentence: On 20 November 1789, the State became the first of the newly created Union to ratify the Bill of Rights.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Constitution of the State of New Jersey of 1776 gave the vote to "all inhabitants" who had a certain level of wealth.

name: new_jersey
sentence: This includes women and blacks, but not married women, because they cannot own property separate from their husbands.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The two parties, in several elections, claimed that the other party had voted unqualified and mocked the use of "jump voters", whether or not they had the right to vote; on the other hand, both parties had passed laws on voting rights.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In 1807, the legislature passed a bill interpreting the Constitution as meaning the universal suffrage of white men, to the exclusion of the poor; the Constitution itself was a legislative law and was not enshrined as the modern Constitution.

name: new_jersey
sentence: On 15 February 1804 New Jersey became the last northern state to abolish slavery and enacted legislation that slowly eliminated existing slavery.

name: new_jersey
sentence: This has led to a gradual decrease in the slave population.

name: new_jersey
sentence: At the end of the civil war, a dozen African Americans from New Jersey were still in servitude.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey voters initially refused to ratify the constitutional amendments prohibiting slavery and granting rights to the black population of the United States.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Industrialization accelerated in the northern part of the State after the completion of the Morris Canal in 1831.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The canal brought coal from the eastern Lehigh Valley into the growing industries of northern New Jersey to Paterson, Newark and Jersey City.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In 1844, the second Constitution of the State was ratified and brought into force.

sentence: The counties thus became districts for the state senate, and a certain realignment of borders (including the creation of Mercer County) followed immediately.

sentence: This provision was maintained in the 1947 Constitution, but was overturned by the United States Supreme Court in 1962 by Baker v. Carr.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Although the government was stronger than in the constitution of 1776, the constitution of 1844 created many offices that were not responsible to him or to the people, and gave him a three-year term, but he could not succeed himself.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey was one of the few states in the Union (the others being Delaware and Kentucky) to choose a candidate other than Abraham Lincoln twice in the national election, and he joined Stephen Douglas (1860) and George B. McClellan (1864) in their campaigns.

sentence: McClellan, originally from Philadelphia, had ties to New Jersey and was officially resident in New Jersey at the time; he later became governor of New Jersey (1878–81).

sentence: During the American Civil War, the state was first led by Republican Governor Charles Smith Olden and then by Democratic Joel Parker.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In the course of the war, more than 80,000 members of the state enlisted in the northern army; unlike many states, some of them from the north, no battles were fought there.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In the industrial revolution, cities like Paterson grew and prospered.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Previously, the economy was largely agrarian, which was a problem because of the failure of crops and poor soil quality.

name: new_jersey
sentence: This has led to a shift towards a more industrialized economy based on manufactured products such as textiles and silk.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The inventor Thomas Edison also became an important figure in the industrial revolution, having obtained 1,093 patents, many of which for inventions he developed while working in New Jersey.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Edison's facilities, first at Menlo Park and then at West Orange, may be considered the first research centres in the United States.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Christie Street at Menlo Park was the first artery in the world to have electric lighting.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Transportation has been greatly improved as locomotion and steamboats have been introduced into New Jersey.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Iron mining was also a leading industry between the mid-19th century and the end of the 19th century.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Peat iron wells in southern New Jersey Pinelands were among the first sources of iron for the new nation.

sentence: Mining gave impetus to new cities and was one of the driving forces behind the need for the Morris Canal.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Zinc mines were also a major industry, particularly the Sterling Hill mine.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey thrived in the 1920s.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The first Miss America Pageant took place in 1921 in Atlantic City, the Holland Tunnel linking Jersey City to Manhattan opened in 1927, and the first drive-in film was presented in 1933 in Camden.

name: new_jersey
sentence: During the Great Depression of the 1930s, the state offered begging permits to unemployed residents, the Zeppelin Hindenburg airship crashed into flames over Lakehurst, and the SS Morro castle ran down near Asbury Park after inflaming itself at sea.

name: new_jersey
sentence: During the two world wars, New Jersey was a centre of war production, particularly shipbuilding.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The construction sites of the Federal Shipbuilding and Drydock Company in Kearny and Newark and the New York Shipbuilding Corporation in Camden produced aircraft carriers, combat ships, cruisers and destroyers.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey manufactured 6.8 per cent of the total U.S. military weapons produced during the Second World War, ranking fifth among the 48 states.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In addition, Fort Dix (1917) (originally called "Camp Dix"), Camp Merritt (1917) and Camp Kilmer (1941) were all built to house and train American soldiers during the two world wars.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey also became a major defence location during the Cold War.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Fourteen Nike missile stations were built to defend the New York and Philadelphia regions.

sentence: The USEnterprise aircraft carrier (CV-6) was briefly moored at the Bayonne military ocean terminal in the 1950s before being sent to Kearney for disposal.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In 1951, the New Jersey Turnpike opened, allowing rapid travel by car and truck between North Jersey (and the New York metropolis) and South Jersey (and Philadelphia metropolis).

name: new_jersey
sentence: On 7 June 1960, an explosion in a CIM-10 Bomarc missile fuel tank caused the accident and plutonium contamination.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In the 1960s, racial riots broke out in many industrial towns in northern Jersey.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Other riots followed the assassination of Martin Luther King Jr. in April 1968, just like in the rest of the country.

sentence: Following an order of the Supreme Court of New Jersey to fund schools fairly, the New Jersey Parliament passed an Income Tax Bill in 1976.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Prior to this bill, the state had no income tax.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In the early 2000s, two light rail networks were opened: Light Rail Hudson-Bergen in Hudson County and River Line between Camden and Trenton.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The aim of these projects was to encourage transit-oriented development in northern Jersey and southern Jersey, respectively.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The HBLR in particular has been credited with a revitalization of Hudson County and Jersey City in particular.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Urban regeneration continued in northern Jersey in the 21st century.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In 2014, Jersey City's estimated population was 262,146, with the largest increase in the population of any municipality in New Jersey since 2010, an increase of 5.9% from the 2010 U.S. Census, when the city's population was listed at 247,597.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Between 2000 and 2010, Newark experienced its first population growth since the 1950s.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey is bordered to the north and northeast by New York (some of which cross the Hudson River, Upper New York Bay, Kill Van Kull, Newark Bay and Arthur Kill); to the east by the Atlantic Ocean; to the south-west by Delaware Bay; and to the west by the Pennsylvania by the Delaware River.

name: new_jersey
sentence: This is the only right-hand border in New Jersey.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey is often divided into three geographic areas: northern Jersey, central Jersey and southern Jersey.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Some New Jersey residents do not see central Jersey as a region in their own right, but others believe it is a distinct geographical and cultural region from the north and south.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Within these regions are five distinct areas, depending on natural geography and population concentration.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The northeast of New Jersey is closest to Manhattan in New York, and up to a million residents travel to the city every day to work, a lot by public transport.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The northwestern part of New Jersey is more woody, rural and mountainous.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Jersey Shore, along the Atlantic coast of central and southern Jersey, has its own natural, residential and cultural features because of its oceanfront location.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Delaware Valley includes counties in the southwestern part of the state, which reside in the Philadelphia metropolitan area.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Pine Barrens region is located in the southern interior of New Jersey.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Covered fairly broadly by the mixed pine and oak forest, it has a much lower population density than most of the rest of the state.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Federal Bureau of Management and Budget divides New Jersey counties into seven metropolitan statistical areas, including 16 in the metropolitan areas of New York or Philadelphia.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Four counties have independent subway areas, and Warren County is part of the Lehigh Valley subway area in Pennsylvania.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey is also at the centre of the northeast megapolis.

name: new_jersey
sentence: High Point, in Montague Township, Sussex County, is the highest elevation in the state at 1,803 feet (550 m) above sea level.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The highest importance of the state is Kitty Ann Mountain in Morris County, at 892 feet.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Palisades are a line of steep cliffs on the west side of the Hudson River, in the counties of Bergen and Hudson.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The major rivers in New Jersey include the Hudson, Delaware, Raritan, Passaic, Hackensack, Rahway, Musconetcong, Mullica, Rancocas, Manasquan, Maurice and Toms rivers.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Due to the geography of the New Jersey Peninsula, sunrise and sunset are visible above the water from different points on the Jersey Shore.

name: new_jersey
sentence: There are two weather conditions in the state.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The southern, central and northeastern parts of the state have a humid subtropical climate, while the northwest has a humid (microthermal) continental climate, with much cooler temperatures due to higher elevations.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey receives between 2,400 and 2,800 hours of sunshine a year.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Climate change affects New Jersey faster than most other United States.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In 2019, New Jersey was one of the warmest states in the nation.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Since 1895, average temperatures have risen by almost 3.6 degrees Fahrenheit, twice the average of the other lower 48 states.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Summers are generally warm and humid, with mean temperatures at 82–87°F (28–31°C) and 60–69°F (16–21°C); however, temperatures above 90°F (32°C) on average 25 days each summer, exceeding 100°F (38°C) in some years.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Winters are generally cold, with mean high temperatures of 34–43°F (1–6°C) and low temperatures of 16–28°F (−9–2°C) for most of the state, but temperatures may fall for short periods below 10°F (−12°C) and sometimes above 50°F (10°C).

name: new_jersey
sentence: The northwestern parts of the state have significantly colder winters, with the sub-0°F (−18 °C) being an almost annual occurrence.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Spring and fall can have large temperature variations, with less humidity than summer.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The USDA Hardiness Zone classification ranges from 6 in the northwestern part of the state to 7B near Cape May.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Extreme temperatures at all times recorded in New Jersey include 110°F (43°C) on July 10, 1936, at Runyon, Middlesex County, and -34°F (−37°C) on January 5, 1904, at River Vale, Bergen County.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Average annual precipitation ranges from 43 to 51 inches (1,100 to 1,300 mm), evenly distributed throughout the year.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Average snowfalls per winter season range from 10 to 15 inches (25 to 38 cm) in the south and near the coast, from 15 to 30 inches (38 to 76 cm) in the northeast and central states, to about 40 to 50 inches (1.0 to 1.3 m) in the northwest highlands, but often vary considerably from year to year.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Precipitation falls on average 120 days per year, with 25 to 30 thunderstorms, most of which occur during the summer.

name: new_jersey
sentence: During the winter and early spring, New Jersey can experience "no'easters", which are capable of causing blizzards or floods throughout the northeastern United States.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Hurricanes and tropical storms (such as tropical storm Floyd in 1999), tornadoes and earthquakes are rare, although New Jersey was hit by a hurricane in 1903, and Hurricane Sandy on October 29, 2012 with the storm that caused the state to fall with winds above 90 mph (145 km/h).

name: new_jersey

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey's economy is multifaceted, but it focuses on the pharmaceutical industry, biotechnology, information technology, financial industry, chemical development, telecommunications, food processing, electrical equipment, printing, publishing and tourism.

sentence: Although New Jersey is home to many energy-intensive industries, its energy consumption accounts for only 2.7 per cent of the total U.S., and its carbon dioxide emissions account for 0.8 per cent of the total U.S.

name: new_york
sentence: New York is a state in the northeastern United States of America.

sentence: Upstate, and New York City, have given strong support to the American civil war, in terms of finance, volunteer soldiers, and supplies.

sentence: More than 53,000 New Yorkers died in service, or about one in seven.

name: new_york
sentence: Since the early 19th century, New York has been the largest port of entry for legal immigration to the United States.

name: new_york
sentence: In the United States, the federal government did not assume direct jurisdiction over immigration until 1890.

name: new_york
sentence: Prior to that date, the issue was delegated to the various states and then by contract between the states and the federal government.

name: new_york
sentence: Most immigrants to New York would land on busy docks along the Hudson and East Rivers in Lower Manhattan.

name: new_york
sentence: On May 4, 1847, the Legislative Assembly of New York State created the Council of Immigration Commissioners to regulate immigration.

name: new_york
sentence: The first permanent immigration depot in New York was established in 1855 at Castle Garden, a fort converted from the time of the War of 1812 in what is now Battery Park, at the tip of Lower Manhattan.

name: new_york
sentence: The first immigrants to arrive at the new depot were aboard three ships that had just been released from quarantine.

name: new_york
sentence: Castle Garden served as a depository for immigrants to New York until its closure on April 18, 1890, when the federal government took control of immigration.

name: new_york
sentence: During this period, more than eight million immigrants crossed its doors (two out of three American immigrants).

name: new_york
sentence: When the federal government took control, it established the Immigration Bureau, which chose the three-acre Ellis Island in Upper New York Harbor for an entry depot.

name: new_york
sentence: Already under federal control, the island had been used as a ammunition depot.

name: new_york
sentence: It was chosen because of its relative isolation with the proximity of New York City and the railway lines of Jersey City, New Jersey, by a short ferry ride.

name: new_york
sentence: While the island was being developed and expanded through land reclamation, the federal government operated a temporary storage facility at Barge's battery-powered office.

name: new_york
sentence: Ellis Island opened its doors on 1 January 1892 and served as a central immigration centre until the passage of the National Origins Act in 1924, thereby reducing immigration.

name: new_york
sentence: After that date, the only immigrants to pass were internally displaced persons or war refugees.

name: new_york
sentence: The island ceased immigration treatment on 12 November 1954, when the last person detained on the island, Norwegian sailor Arne Peterssen, was released.

name: new_york
sentence: He had exceeded his shore leave and left the 10:15 a.m. ferry towards Manhattan to return to his ship.

name: new_york
sentence: More than 12 million immigrants passed through the island of Ellis between 1892 and 1954.

name: new_york
sentence: More than 100 million Americans across the United States can trace their ancestry to these immigrants.

name: new_york
sentence: Ellis Island has been the subject of a long-standing border and jurisdictional dispute between the State of New York and the State of New Jersey, as both argued.

name: new_york
sentence: The issue was resolved in 1998 by the United States Supreme Court, which ruled that the original island of 3.3 acres (1.3 ha) was the territory of New York State and that the balance of 27.5 acres (11 ha) added after 1834 per landfill was in New Jersey.

name: new_york
sentence: The island was added to the National Park Service System in May 1965 by President Lyndon B. Johnson and is still owned by the federal government as part of the Statue of Liberty National Monument.

name: new_york
sentence: Ellis Island was opened to the public as a museum of immigration in 1990.

name: new_york
sentence: On September 11, 2001, two of the four hijacked aircraft were stolen from the original World Trade Center Twin Towers in Lower Manhattan and the towers collapsed.

name: new_york
sentence: 7 World Trade Center also collapsed due to damage caused by fires.

name: new_york
sentence: The other buildings of the World Trade Center complex were damaged beyond the repairs and demolished shortly thereafter.

name: new_york
sentence: The collapse of the twin towers caused considerable damage and the death of 2,753 victims, 147 of whom were on both planes.

name: new_york
sentence: Since 11 September, most of Lower Manhattan has been restored.

sentence: Over the past few years, more than 7,000 rescue workers and residents of the region have contracted several life-threatening diseases and some have died.

sentence: A memorial on the site, the Museum and the National Memorial of September 11, was opened to the public on September 11, 2011.

sentence: Upon its completion in 2014, the new One World Trade Center became the tallest skyscraper in the Western Hemisphere, at 1776 feet (541 m), to symbolize the year America gained its independence, 1776.

name: new_york
sentence: On October 29 and 30, 2012, Hurricane Sandy caused massive destruction on the banks of the state, ravaging parts of New York City, Long Island and South Westchester with record storm surges, severe flooding and violent winds causing power outages for hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers, resulting in fuel shortages and disruptions to public transit systems.

name: new_york
sentence: The storm and its profound effects led to discussions on the construction of sea walls and other coastal barriers around the shores of New York City and Long Island in order to minimize the risks arising from another such occurrence.

name: new_york
sentence: This risk is considered highly likely due to global warming and sea level rise.

sentence: Nearly 50 per cent of known national cases were in the state, with one third of known US cases in New York.

sentence: During the pandemic, a federal judge ruled that Cuomo and De Blasio exceeded authority by limiting religious gatherings to 25% when others operated to 50%.

sentence: The New York government released a new seal, coat of arms and flag in April during the pandemic, adding "E pluribus unum" below the state's motto.

name: new_york
sentence: New York covers 54,555 square miles (141,300 km2) and ranks 27th in size among the largest states.

name: new_york
sentence: The highest altitude in New York is Mount Marcy in the Adirondacks, 5,344 feet (1,629 meters) above sea level; while the lowest point in the state is at sea level on the Atlantic Ocean.

name: new_york
sentence: Unlike New York City's urban landscape, the vast majority of the state's geographic region is dominated by grasslands, forests, rivers, farms, mountains and lakes.

name: new_york
sentence: Most of the southern part of the state is based on the Allegheny Plateau, which extends from the southeastern United States to the Catskill Mountains; the New York State section is known as the Southern Tier.

name: new_york
sentence: The Adirondack Mountains, with vast wilderness areas, are to the west of the Lake Champlain Valley.

name: new_york
sentence: The large Appalachian Valley dominates eastern New York and houses the Lake Champlain Valley as its northern half and the Hudson Valley as its southern half within the state.

name: new_york
sentence: The Tug Hill region is a cuesta located east of Lake Ontario.

sentence: The top and bottom are often used informally to distinguish the city of New York or its largest metropolitan area from the rest of New York State.

name: new_york
sentence: The location of a border between the two is a matter of great discord.

sentence: New York contains part of the schist Marcellus, which extends into Ohio and Pennsylvania.

sentence: Of the total area of New York State, 13.6% consists of water.

name: new_york
sentence: Much of New York's borders are in the water, as is the case for New York City: four of its five boroughs are located on three islands at the mouth of the Hudson River: Manhattan Island, Staten Island, and Long Island, which contains Brooklyn and Queens at its western end.

name: new_york
sentence: The boundaries of the state include a water limit in (hourly from the west) two Great Lakes (Lake Erie and Lake Ontario, which are connected by the Niagara River); the provinces of Ontario and Quebec in Canada, with New York and Ontario sharing the archipelago of the Thousand Islands within the St. Lawrence River, while most of its border with Quebec is on land; it shares Lake Champlain with the State of Vermont, New England; the State of New England of Massachusetts primarily has a land boundary; New York extends to Long Island Sound and the Atlantic Ocean, sharing a water boundary with Rhode Island, while Connecticut has land and maritime boundaries.

name: new_york
sentence: With the exception of areas near New York Harbour and the Upper Delaware River, New York has a predominantly land border with two Mid-Atlantic states, New Jersey and Pennsylvania.

name: new_york
sentence: New York is the only state that includes within its borders parts of the Great Lakes and Atlantic Ocean.

name: new_york
sentence: The Hudson River begins near Tear Lake from the clouds and flows south into the eastern part of the state, without draining George or Champlain lakes.

sentence: Lake George flows at its north end into Lake Champlain, whose north end extends to Canada, where it flows into the Richelieu River, and eventually into the St. Lawrence River.

sentence: The western part of the State is drained by the Allegheny River and the Susquehanna and Delaware rivers.

sentence: Niagara Falls are divided between New York and Ontario as they flow over the Niagara River from Lake Erie to Lake Ontario.

name: new_york
sentence: In general, New York has a damp continental climate, although under the climate classification of Köppen, New York City has a humid subtropical climate.

name: new_york
sentence: The weather in New York City is strongly influenced by two continental air masses: a warm and humid southwest and a cold and dry northwest.

name: new_york
sentence: The lower part of New York State, which includes the City of New York, Long Island and the lower parts of the Hudson Valley, has rather warm summers with periods of high humidity and relatively mild cold and humid winters compared to temperatures at Upstate New York due to lower elevations in the descending region, proximity to the Atlantic Ocean, and relatively lower latitude.

name: new_york
sentence: At the top of New York, summers are warm, marked by short and occasional intervals of dirty conditions, with long and cold winters.

name: new_york
sentence: The west of New York, particularly the Tug Hill area, receives heavy lake snow, especially during the early winter months, before the surface of Lake Ontario itself is covered with ice.

name: new_york
sentence: The summer climate is cool in the Adirondacks, Catskills and at higher altitudes of the South Third.

name: new_york
sentence: Buffalo and its metropolitan area are described as climate change shelters because of their weather patterns in western New York.

name: new_york
sentence: Summer daytime temperatures range from the high 1970s to the low 1980s (25-28°C), over most of the state.

name: new_york
sentence: In most winter seasons, temperatures can be expected to be −13°F (−25°C) or lower in the northern (northern) highlands and 5°F (−15°C) or colder in the southwest and east-central South Tier highlands.

name: new_york
sentence: New York had a record temperature of 108°F (42.2°C) on July 22, 1926.

name: new_york
sentence: Its lowest winter temperature was -52°F (−46.7°C) in 1979.

name: new_york
sentence: Some species that can be found in this state are American ginseng, starred stonewort, waterthym, water chestnut, eastern poisoned ivy, poisoned sumac, giant seaweed, cow parsnip and common nettle.

name: new_york
sentence: There are more than 20 species of mammals, more than 20 species of birds, some species of amphibians, and several species of reptiles.

name: new_york
sentence: New York's mammal species are the white-footed mouse, the lowest shrew in North America, the small brown bat, the muskrat, the eastern grey squirrel, the eastern cotton tail, the killer whale, the striped gull, the fisherman, the North American river otter, the raccoon, the bobcat, the coyote, the red fox, the white-tailed deer, the moose and the American black bear.

name: new_york
sentence: Some of New York's bird species are collared pheasant, northern bobwhite, ruffed grouse, wild turkey, blue jay, eastern blue bird, American robin, and black chichade.

sentence: New York's sea or coastal birds are large blue herons, killer deer, northern cardinals, American herring gulls and common terns.

sentence: The reptiles that can be seen in the land areas of New York are the queen snake, the massasauga, the master of hell, the diamond-backed terrapine, the spotted turtle and the speckled turtle.

sentence: New York has numerous state parks and two major forest reserves.

sentence: The Niagara Falls State Park, founded in 1885, is the oldest state park in the United States and the first to be created through a prominent estate.

sentence: The park is larger than the combined Yellowstone, Everglades, Glacier and Grand Canyon national parks.

sentence: It is larger than Yellowstone, Yosemite, Grand Canyon, Glacier, and Olympic National Parks.

sentence: Catskill Park is protected by a law passed in 1885, which states that its lands must be preserved and never be offered for sale or leased.

sentence: The National Baptist Convention (USA) and the Progressive National Baptist Convention were the largest Protestant churches historically black in New York.

name: new_york
sentence: About 10 per cent of New York Christians are evangelical Protestants.

name: new_york
sentence: Eastern Orthodox and Eastern Orthodox collectively represented 1% of the religious population alongside Jehovah's Witnesses and other Christians.

name: new_york
sentence: Non-Christian religions make up 12% of the religious population.

name: new_york
sentence: Judaism is the second most important religion since 2014.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2010, 588,500 people practised Orthodox Judaism.

name: new_york
sentence: A little over 392,953 professed Islam.

name: new_york
sentence: New York is home to the oldest Zoroastrian Fire Temple in the United States.

name: new_york
sentence: Less than 1% of New York's population practice New Age and contemporary paganism.

name: new_york
sentence: Amerindian religions are also a significant minority.

name: new_york
sentence: Irreligious is a growing community in the New York metropolitan area.

name: new_york
sentence: State-wide, 17 per cent do nothing in particular and 5 per cent are atheistic and agnostic.

name: new_york
sentence: Approximately 3.8% of the adult population in the state identifies as lesbian, gay, bisexual or transgender.

name: new_york
sentence: It is a total population of 570,388 LGBT adults.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2010, the number of same-sex households was about 48,932.

name: new_york
sentence: New York is the fifth state to allow homosexual marriages after New Hampshire.

name: new_york
sentence: Michael Bloomberg, Mayor of New York, said that "homosexual marriages in New York generated approximately $259 million in economic impact and $16 million in municipal revenue" in the first year after the passage of the Marriage Equality Act.

name: new_york
sentence: Same-sex marriages in New York were legalized on 24 June 2011 and were allowed to commence 30 days thereafter.

name: new_york
sentence: New York City is also home to the largest transgender population in the United States, estimated at 25,000 in 2016.

name: new_york
sentence: The annual New York Pride March (or gay pride parade) crosses 5th Avenue in Manhattan, ending at Greenwich Village, and rivals the Sao Paulo Gay Pride Parade as the largest pride parade in the world, attracting tens of thousands of participants and millions of spectators on the sidewalks each June.

name: new_york
sentence: The Stonewall riots were a series of spontaneous and violent protests by members of the gay community against a police raid that took place in the early morning of June 28, 1969, at Stonewall Inn, Greenwich Village, Lower Manhattan.

name: new_york
sentence: They are widely seen as the most important event leading to the gay liberation movement and the modern struggle for LGBT rights.

name: new_york
sentence: In June 2017, plans were announced for the first official LGBT monument commissioned by the State of New York, unlike the Stonewall National Monument, commissioned by the U.S. federal government.

name: new_york
sentence: The State Monument should be built in Hudson River Park in Manhattan, near the Hudson River wharves, which have served as important historical symbols of New York's central role as a meeting place and refuge for LGBT communities.

name: new_york
sentence: As early as 2017, New York State planned to host the largest international celebration of LGBT pride in 2019, known as Stonewall 50 – WorldPride NYC 2019, to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the Stonewall riots.

name: new_york
sentence: In New York, the 2019 Stonewall 50–WorldPride NYC events produced by Heritage of Pride were enhanced through a partnership with the LGBT division of the I LOVE NY program and included a reception centre during the weeks surrounding the Stonewall 50 / WorldPride events that was open to all.

name: new_york
sentence: Other commemorative, cultural and educational arts programs on the occasion of the 50th anniversary of the rebellion at Stonewall Inn took place throughout the city and around the world; Stonewall 50 – WorldPride NYC 2019 was the largest celebration of LGBT pride in history, attracting approximately five million people.

name: new_york
sentence: Brooklyn Liberation March, the largest event on transgender rights in LGBTQ history, took place on June 14, 2020, from Grand Army Plaza to Fort Greene, Brooklyn, and focused on supporting the lives of black transgenderers, attracting between 15,000 and 20,000 participants.

name: new_york
sentence: New York's 2018 gross national product was $1.7 trillion.

name: new_york
sentence: If the state of New York were an independent nation, it would be the 11th largest economy in the world.

name: new_york
sentence: However, in 2013, the multi-state metropolitan statistical area, centred on the city of New York, produced a gross metropolitan product (GMP) of nearly $1.4 trillion, while in 2012, the corresponding combined statistical area produced a GMP of more than $1.7 trillion, both of which ranked first in the country with a wide margin and behind the GDP of only nine countries.

name: new_york
sentence: Anchored by Wall Street in the Financial District of Lower Manhattan, New York City was called both the most economical city and the main financial centre in the world.

name: new_york
sentence: Lower Manhattan is the third largest business district in the United States and houses the New York Stock Exchange at Wall Street, and NASDAQ at 165 Broadway, representing the largest and second largest stock exchanges in the world, measured both by the average volume of daily transactions and by the total market capitalization of their listed companies in 2013.

name: new_york
sentence: The investment bank charges on Wall Street amounted to approximately $40 billion in 2012, while in 2013, senior New York bank managers who manage the risk management and compliance functions earned up to $324,000 per year.

name: new_york
sentence: During the 2013–14 fiscal year, the Wall Street securities industry generated 19% of New York's tax revenues.

name: new_york
sentence: New York City remains the world's largest trading centre in the public capital and debt markets, in part because of the size and financial development of the U.S. economy.

name: new_york
sentence: New York is also the leader in hedge fund management

name: new_york
sentence: Several investment banks and investment managers based in Manhattan are major participants in other global financial centres.

name: new_york
sentence: New York is also the main commercial banking centre in the United States.

name: new_york
sentence: Many of the world's biggest media conglomerates are also based in the city.

name: new_york
sentence: Manhattan contained approximately 520 million square feet (48.1 million square feet) of office space in 2013, making it the largest office market in the United States, while Midtown Manhattan is the nation's largest central business district.

name: new_york
sentence: Silicon Alley, centered in New York, has become a metanym for the sphere encompassing the high-tech and entrepreneurship ecosystem of the New York metropolitan area; in 2015, Silicon Alley generated more than $7.3 billion in venture capital investments.

name: new_york
sentence: High-tech industries, including digital media, biotechnology, software development, game design and other areas in the field of information technology, are growing, supported by New York's position at the terminus of several transatlantic fibre optic lines, its intellectual capital, as well as its growing external wireless connectivity.

name: new_york
sentence: In December 2014, the State of New York announced a $50 million venture capital fund to encourage companies working in the field of biotechnology and advanced materials; according to Governor Andrew Cuomo, start-up money would help entrepreneurs put their research on the market.

name: new_york
sentence: On December 19, 2011, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced his choice from Cornell University and the Technion-Israel Institute of Technology to build a $2 billion college of applied science on Roosevelt Island in Manhattan to transform New York into the world's first technological capital.

name: new_york
sentence: Albany, Saratoga County, Rensselaer County, and the Hudson Valley, collectively recognized as the Eastern New York Technology Valley, have experienced significant growth in high-tech computing equipment, with major advances in nanotechnology, digital electronics design, and the manufacture of microchip integrated circuits dependent on water and electricity, involving companies including IBM and its Thomas J. Watson Research Centre, as well as the three foreign companies, GlobalFoundries, Samsung and Taiwan Semiconductor, among others.

name: new_york
sentence: The region's high-tech ecosystem is supported by technology-based academic institutions, including the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute and SUNY Polytechnic Institute.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2015, Tech Valley, which straddles both sides of the Adirondack Northway and New York Thruway, generated more than $163 million in venture capital investments.

name: new_york
sentence: The Rochester region is important in the field of photographic processing and imaging as well as in the incubation of an increasingly diverse high-tech sphere encompassing STEM domains, as well as the results of private start-up companies working with major academic institutions, including the University of Rochester and Cornell University.

name: new_york
sentence: Westchester County has developed a booming biotechnology sector in the 21st century, with over $1 billion in private investment expected to begin in 2016.

name: new_york
sentence: Creative industries, which generate and disseminate knowledge and information, such as new media, digital media, film and television production, advertising, fashion, design and architecture, account for an increasing share of employment, with the City of New York having a strong competitive advantage in these industries.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2014, New York State offered tax incentives of up to $420 million per year for the production of films within the state, the most generous tax rebate among U.S. states.

name: new_york
sentence: New York also attracted higher visual effects jobs by further increasing its tax credit to a maximum of 35 per cent for post-film production in Upstate New York.

name: new_york
sentence: The filmed entertainment industry grew in New York, contributing nearly $9 billion to the New York economy in 2015.

name: new_york
sentence: I Love New York is a slogan, logo and state song that are the basis of an advertising campaign and has been used since 1977 to promote tourism in New York State, including New York City.

name: new_york
sentence: The logo of the brand is the property of New York State Empire State Development.

name: new_york
sentence: The Broadway League reported that Broadway's programs sold approximately $1.27 billion in tickets for the 2013–14 season, an increase of 11.4% from $1.39 billion for the 2012–13 season.

name: new_york
sentence: Participation in 2013–14 was $12.21 million, an increase of 5.5% compared to the $11.57 million in the 2012–13 season.

name: new_york
sentence: New York exports a wide variety of products such as prepared food, computers and electronics, cut diamonds and other products.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2007, the Government exported a total of $71.1 billion in goods, with Canada ($15 billion), Switzerland ($5.9 billion), Israel ($4.9 billion) and Hong Kong ($3.4 billion) the top five foreign export markets.

name: new_york
sentence: New York's largest imports are oil, gold, aluminum, natural gas, electricity, rough diamonds and softwood lumber.

name: new_york
sentence: The state also has a large manufacturing sector that includes clothing printing and production, primarily in New York; and furs, railway equipment, automotive parts and bus line vehicles, concentrated in Upstate areas.

name: new_york
sentence: New York is the third largest producer of grapes in the country, and the second largest producer of wine, behind California.

name: new_york
sentence: The southern hills of Finger Lakes, the Hudson Valley, the northern fork of Long Island and the south shore of Lake Erie are the main wine-growing and wine-growing areas of New York, with many vineyards.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2012, New York had 320 wineries and 37,000 hectares of vines, generating full-time jobs for nearly 25,000 people and annual wages above $1.1 billion, and producing $4.8 billion in direct economic impact of grapes, grape juice and wine and grape products.

name: new_york
sentence: The New York agricultural industry is one of the largest producers overall, ranking among the top five countries for agricultural products, including maple syrup, apples, cherries, cabbage, dairy products, onions and potatoes.

name: new_york
sentence: The State is the largest cabbage producer in the United States

name: new_york
sentence: The government owns about a quarter of its agricultural land and produced $3.4 billion in agricultural products in 2001.

name: new_york
sentence: The south shore of Lake Ontario offers the right mix of soils and microclimates for many apple, cherries, plums, pears and peaches.

name: new_york
sentence: Apples are also cultivated in the Hudson Valley and near Lake Champlain.

name: new_york
sentence: A commercial medium-sized saltwater fishery is conducted along the Atlantic side of Long Island.

name: new_york
sentence: The main catches are clams, lobsters, squid and folds.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2017, New York State consumed 156,370 gigawatt hours (GWh) of electric energy.

name: new_york
sentence: Lower-state areas (Hudson Valley, New York and Long Island) consumed 66% of this amount.

name: new_york
sentence: The outermost regions produced 50 % of this amount.

name: new_york
sentence: The maximum load in 2017 was 29 699 MW.

name: new_york
sentence: The resource capacity in 2017 was 42,839 MW.

name: new_york
sentence: NYISO's market monitor described the overall average price of electricity as a range (a single value was not provided) from $25 per MWh to $53 per MWh in 2017.

name: new_york
sentence: At the post-secondary level, the State-wide public university system is the State University of New York (SUNY).

name: new_york
sentence: SUNY includes 64 community colleges, technical colleges, undergraduate colleges and doctoral institutions, including several universities.

name: new_york
sentence: New York's flagship university is the University of Buffalo, founded by U.S. President Billard Fillmore.

name: new_york
sentence: Along with Buffalo University, Binghamton University also ranks high in the ranking of the best public universities in the United States.

name: new_york
sentence: New York City has its own City University of New York (CUNY), which is funded by the city.

name: new_york
sentence: Columbia University, Cornell University and New York University are among the most important higher education institutions in New York, all world-renowned private universities and members of the Association of American Universities, the first group of research universities in the United States.

name: new_york
sentence: Other major private universities include Syracuse University and Fordham University.

name: new_york
sentence: The smallest private institutions of higher education are Rockefeller University, Mercy College, New York Institute of Technology, Rensselaer Polytechnic, Yeshiva University and Hofstra University.

name: new_york
sentence: There are also a multitude of graduate schools in New York State, including schools of medicine, law and engineering.

name: new_york
sentence: The U.S. Army Service Academy, West Point, is located just south of Newburgh on the west bank of the Hudson River.

name: new_york
sentence: The Federal Merchant Marine Academy is at Kings Point on Long Island.

name: new_york
sentence: A number of private institutions of selective liberal arts are located in New York.

name: new_york
sentence: These include Bard College, Barnard College, Colgate University, Hamilton College, Hobart and William Smith Colleges, Marist College, Sarah Lawrence College, Skidmore College, Union College, and Vassar College.

name: new_york
sentence: Two of these schools, Barnard and Vassar, are members of the Seven Sisters elite, originally all women's schools with links to the Ivy League.

name: new_york
sentence: Barnard was affiliated with Columbia University, its neighbour in Manhattan, and Vassar became a co-educator in 1969 after refusing an offer to merge with Yale University.

name: new_york
sentence: New York is also home to what is widely regarded as the best performing arts schools in the world.

name: new_york
sentence: The Juilliard School, located in Manhattan's Upper West Side, is one of the world's leading schools of music and dance.

name: new_york
sentence: The Eastman School of Music, a professional school at the University of Rochester, has been ranked first among American music schools by US News & World Report for five consecutive years.

name: new_york
sentence: The New York State University accredits and establishes standards for primary, middle and secondary education in the State, while the New York State Department of Education supervises public schools and monitors their standardized testing.

name: new_york
sentence: The New York City Department of Education operates the New York City Public School System.

name: new_york
sentence: In 1894, reflecting general racial discrimination, the State passed a law enabling communities to establish separate schools for children of African-American descent.

name: new_york
sentence: In 1900, the State passed another law requiring integrated schools.

name: new_york
sentence: In fiscal year 2013, New York spent more money on public education per student than any other State, according to U.S. Census Bureau statistics.

name: new_york
sentence: New York has one of the largest and oldest transport infrastructure in the country.

name: new_york
sentence: The engineering problems posed by the complex terrain of the state and the unique infrastructure problems of the city of New York caused by urban congestion have had to be overcome forever.

name: new_york
sentence: The population expansion of the state followed the path of the first waterways, first the Hudson River and the Mohawk River, then the Erie Canal.

name: new_york
sentence: In the 19th century, railways were built along the river valleys, followed by the New York State Thruway in the 20th century.

name: new_york
sentence: The New York State Department of Transportation (NYSDOT) is the New York Government Department responsible for the development and operation of highways, railways, public transport systems, ports, waterways and air facilities in New York State.

name: new_york
sentence: The NYSDOT is headquartered at 50 Wolf Road in Colonie, Albany County.

name: new_york
sentence: The New York and New Jersey Port Authority (PANYNJ) is a joint venture between the States of New York and New Jersey and authorized by the American Congress, established in 1921 by an inter-State pact, which oversees much of the regional transportation infrastructure, including bridges, tunnels, airports and seaports, within the geographic jurisdiction of the Port of New York and New Jersey.

name: new_york
sentence: This harbour area of 1,500 km2 (3,900 km2) is generally covered within a 25 km (40 km) radius of the National Monument of the Statue of Liberty.

name: new_york
sentence: The headquarters of the Port Authority are located at the 4 World Trade Center in Lower Manhattan.

name: new_york
sentence: In addition to the well-known New York Metro system, which is confined to the City of New York, four suburban rail networks enter and leave the city: the Long Island Railway, the Metro-North Railway, the Trans-Hudson Harbour Authority and five of New Jersey Transit's railway lines.

name: new_york
sentence: The New York City Department of Transportation (NYCDOT) is the New York City government agency responsible for the management of much of New York's transportation infrastructure.

name: new_york
sentence: Other cities in New York have urban and regional public transportation.

name: new_york
sentence: In Buffalo, the Niagara Frontier Transportation Authority manages Buffalo Metro Rail's light rail system; in Rochester, Rochester Metro operated from 1927 to 1956, but became obsolete as the government and the federal government invested in roads.

name: new_york
sentence: The State Department of Motor Vehicles of New York (NYSDMV or DMV) is the government agency responsible for registering and inspecting motor vehicles and other motor vehicles, as well as authorizing drivers in New York State.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2008, NYSDMV had 11,284,546 driving licences and 10,697,644 vehicle registrations in force.

name: new_york
sentence: All gasoline vehicles registered in New York State must undergo an emission inspection every 12 months to ensure that environmental quality controls prevent air pollution.

name: new_york
sentence: Diesel-powered vehicles with a gross weight of more than 8,500 pounds registered in most of the counties of Downstate New York are subject to an annual emission inspection.

name: new_york
sentence: All vehicles registered in New York State must be subject to an annual safety inspection.

name: new_york
sentence: Portions of the transportation system are intermodal, allowing passengers to easily move from one mode of transport to another.

name: new_york
sentence: One of the most notable examples is AirTrain JFK, which allows rail passengers to travel directly to the John F. Kennedy International Airport terminals and the New York Underground Metro.

name: new_york
sentence: The New York Government embodies the Government structure of the State of New York as established by the Constitution of the State of New York.

name: new_york
sentence: It consists of three branches: executive, legislative and judicial.

name: new_york
sentence: The Governor is the Head of the Executive of the State and is assisted by the Lieutenant Governor.

name: new_york
sentence: Both are elected on the same note.

name: new_york
sentence: Other elected members include the Attorney General and the Controller.

name: new_york
sentence: The Secretary of State, former elected official, is currently appointed by the Governor.

name: new_york
sentence: The Legislative Assembly of New York State is bicameral and consists of the New York State Senate and the New York State Assembly.

name: new_york
sentence: The Assembly consists of 150 members, while the Senate varies in its membership, which currently has 63 members.

name: new_york
sentence: The Legislature has the power to make laws, subject to the Governor's power to veto a bill.

name: new_york
sentence: However, the veto may be cancelled by the legislator if there is a two-thirds majority in favour of an overrun in each chamber.

name: new_york
sentence: Permanent laws of a general character are codified in the consolidated laws of New York.

name: new_york
sentence: The highest court of appeal in the unified justice system is the Court of Appeal, while the first court of first instance is the County Court (or the Supreme Court of New York).

name: new_york
sentence: The Supreme Court also acts as an intermediate court of appeal for many cases, and local courts deal with a variety of other issues, including small disputes, traffic tickets and local zoning issues, and are the starting point for all criminal cases.

name: new_york
sentence: The courts in New York City are the largest local judicial system.

name: new_york
sentence: The State is divided into counties, cities, towns and villages, all of which are municipal corporations vis-à-vis their own governments, as well as various societies that serve unique purposes that are also local governments, such as school districts, fire districts and New York State public utility corporations, often referred to as authorities or development societies.

name: new_york
sentence: Each municipal society is given different powers of home government, as provided for in the New York Constitution.

name: new_york
sentence: The State also has 10 Indian reserves.

name: new_york
sentence: There have been several secession movements in the State of New York.

name: new_york
sentence: Proposals include a State of Long Island, composed of everything on the island outside New York; a State called Niagara, the counties of western New York State; the counties of northern New York State called Upstate New York; making New York City a State; a proposal for a new County of Peconic in eastern Long Island; and for the borough of Staten Island to separate from New York City.

name: new_york
sentence: The death penalty was reintroduced in 1995 under the administration of Pataki, but the law was declared unconstitutional in 2004, when the New York Court of Appeal ruled in People v. LaValle that it violated the State Constitution.

name: new_york
sentence: The remaining death penalty was commuted by the court to life imprisonment in 2007, in People v. John Taylor, and death row was dissolved in 2008, by an order of Governor David Paterson.

name: new_york
sentence: There have been no executions in New York since 1963.

name: new_york
sentence: Legislative efforts to amend the law had failed and the death penalty was no longer required at the state level, although certain crimes falling within the federal government's jurisdiction were punishable by the federal death penalty.

name: new_york
sentence: New York is represented by Chuck Schumer and Kirsten Gillibrand in the United States Senate.

name: new_york
sentence: There are 27 Congressional districts, the third largest number of Congressional districts, equal to that of Florida and behind that of California 53 and Texas 36.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2019, 21 districts are represented by members of the Democratic Party, while 6 are represented by Republicans.

name: new_york
sentence: Representation was reduced by 29 in 2013 due to the slowdown in the overall population growth of the state compared to the overall national population growth.

name: new_york
sentence: New York had 29 votes in the national presidential elections, down from its 47-vote summit in 1933 to 1953.

name: new_york
sentence: The state has a strong imbalance in payments with the federal government.

name: new_york
sentence: According to the New York State Comptroller's Office, New York received 91 cents of services for every dollar it sent to the United States federal government in fiscal year 2013; New York ranked 46th in the federal balance of payments to the state on a per capita basis.

name: new_york
sentence: In April 2016, Democrats represented a plurality of voters in New York, more than twice as many registered voters as any other political party.

name: new_york
sentence: Since the second half of the twentieth century, New York has generally supported Democratic Party candidates in the national elections.

name: new_york
sentence: Democratic President Barack Obama won the state of New York by more than 25 percentage points in 2012 and 2008.

name: new_york
sentence: New York, along with the other major cities of the state, including Albany, Buffalo, Rochester, Yonkers and Syracuse, are important democratic bastions, with liberal politics.

name: new_york
sentence: However, the rural areas of New York State are generally more conservative than cities and tend to favour Republicans.

name: new_york
sentence: Largely populated suburban areas, such as Westchester County and Long Island, have crossed the main parties since the 1980s, but most often they support the Democrats.

name: new_york
sentence: New York is the largest source of political fund-raising in the United States for both major parties.

name: new_york
sentence: Four of the nation's top five postal codes for political contributions are in Manhattan.

name: new_york
sentence: The top postal code, 10021 on the Upper East Side, generated the most money for the 2000 presidential campaigns of George W. Bush and Al Gore.

name: new_york
sentence: The State of New York has the distinction of being the State of origin of the two major parties appointed in three presidential elections.

name: new_york
sentence: The 1904 presidential election saw former New York governor and outgoing president Theodore Roosevelt face Alton B. Parker, chief justice of the New York Court of Appeal.

name: new_york
sentence: The 1944 presidential election had Franklin D. Roosevelt, following the footsteps of his cousin Theodore as former governor of New York and outgoing president running for re-election against the current governor of New York Thomas E. Dewey.

name: new_york
sentence: In the 2016 presidential election, the former U.S. Senator of New York Hillary Clinton, resident of Chappaqua, was the Democratic Party candidate.

name: new_york
sentence: The Republican Party candidate was the businessman Donald Trump, a Manhattan resident and a Queens native.

name: new_york
sentence: New York City is an important centre for international diplomacy.

name: new_york
sentence: United Nations Headquarters has been located on the eastern side of Midtown Manhattan since 1952.

name: new_york
sentence: The state of New York is geographically home to a National Football League team, the Buffalo Bills, based in the Buffalo suburbs of Orchard Park.

name: new_york
sentence: Although the New York Giants and the New York Jets represent the New York metropolitan area and were previously located in New York City, they play at the MetLife Stadium, located in East Rutherford, New Jersey.

name: new_york
sentence: New York also has two major League baseball teams, the New York Yankees (based in the Bronx) and the New York Mets (based in the Queens).

name: new_york
sentence: Minor league baseball teams also play in New York State, including the Long Island Ducks, Brooklyn Cyclones and Staten Island Yankees, as well as Rochester Red Wings, Binghamton Rumble Ponies, Syracuse Mets, Auburn Doubledays, Batavia Muckdogs, Hudson Valley Renegades and Buffalo Bisons.

name: new_york
sentence: New York City is home to three National Hockey League franchises: the New York Rangers in Manhattan, the New York Islanders in Brooklyn and Nassau County in Long Island, and the Buffalo Sabres.

name: new_york
sentence: New York has two National Basketball Association teams, the New York Knicks in Manhattan, and the Brooklyn Nets in Brooklyn.

name: new_york
sentence: New York City is the seat of a franchise of Major League Soccer, New York City FC, currently playing in the Bronx.

name: new_york
sentence: Although the New York Red Bulls represent the metropolitan area of New York, they play Red Bull Arena in Harrison, New Jersey.

name: new_york
sentence: New York hosted the 1932 and 1980 Olympic Winter Games at Lake Placid.

name: new_york
sentence: The 1980 Games are known for the U.S.-U.S. ice hockey game known as the Miracle on Ice, during which a group of American students and amateurs beat the highly favoured Soviet 4–3 national ice hockey team and won the gold medal against Finland.

name: new_york
sentence: With St. Moritz, Switzerland and Innsbruck, Austria, Lake Placid is one of three cities to have hosted the Olympic Winter Games twice.

name: new_york
sentence: New York bid for the 2012 Summer Olympics but lost to London.

name: new_york
sentence: Several U.S. national sports halls are or have been located in New York.

name: new_york
sentence: National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum is located in Cooperstown, Otsego County.

name: new_york
sentence: The Saratoga Springs National Race and Hall of Fame Museum in Saratoga County honours achievements in the sport of pure-bred horse racing.

name: new_york
sentence: The physical establishment of the National Soccer Hall of Fame in Oneonta, also in Otsego County, was closed in 2010, although the organization itself continued its inductions.

name: new_york
sentence: The United States Open Tennis Championships are one of four Grand Slam tennis tournaments in the world and take place at the National Tennis Center of Flushing Meadows–Corona Park, Queens District, New York.

name: new_york
sentence: New York State is also home to many Division 1 intercollegial sports programs.

name: new_york
sentence: The flagship university at New York State University in Buffalo is the Buffalo Bulls.

name: new_york
sentence: The intercollegial teams at Syracuse University are the Orange Syracuse.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina is a state in the southeastern United States.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina is the 28th largest and 9th most populous of the 50 United States.

name: north_carolina
sentence: It is bordered by Virginia in the north, the Atlantic Ocean in the east, Georgia and South Carolina in the south, and Tennessee in the west.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Raleigh is the capital of the state, and Charlotte is its largest city.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Charlotte's metropolitan area, with an estimated population of 2,569,213 in 2018, is the most populated metropolitan area of North Carolina, the 23rd most populated in the United States, and the largest banking centre in the nation after New York City.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Raleigh metropolitan area is the second largest metropolitan area in the state, with an estimated population of 1,362,540 in 2018, and is home to the largest research park in the United States, Research Triangle Park.

name: north_carolina

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina is bordered by South Carolina to the south, Georgia to the southwest, Tennessee to the west, Virginia to the north and the Atlantic Ocean to the east.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The U.S. Census Bureau places North Carolina in the South Atlantic division of the southern region.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina consists of three major geographic areas: the Atlantic coastal plain, which occupies the eastern part of the state, the central region of Piedmont, and the western mountainous region, which is part of the Appalachians.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The coastal plain includes more precisely defined areas such as the outer shores, a chain of sandy and narrow islands separated from the continent by sounds or inlets, including the Albemarle Strait and Pamlico Strait, the tidal waters region, the home of the venous flyer and the inland coastal plain, where long-leaved pines are native.

name: north_carolina
sentence: So many ships have been lost off Cape Hatteras that the area is known as the "Graveyard of the Atlantic"; more than a thousand ships have sank in these waters since the records began in 1526.

sentence: The most famous of them is the revenge of the Queen Anne (flagship of the Black Barbe pirate), who failed at Beaufort Inlet in 1718.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The coastal plain passes to the Piedmont region along the fall line of the Atlantic coast, the altitude at which the waterfalls appear for the first time on rivers and streams.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Piedmont region in Central North Carolina is the most populated region of the state, with the six largest cities in the state per population.

name: north_carolina
sentence: It consists of a gently sloping country often broken by low hills or mountain ridges.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Small, isolated, deeply eroded mountain ranges are located in Piedmont, including the Sauratown Mountains, Pilot Mountain, Uwharrie Mountains, Crowder's Mountain, King's Pinnacle Mountains, Brushy Mountains and the South Mountains.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Piedmont extends from approximately 91 metres to the east to approximately 1,500 feet (460 metres) to the west.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The western part of the State is part of the range of Appalachians.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Black Mountains are the highest in the eastern U.S. and peak at Mount Mitchell at 2684 feet (2,037 m), the highest point east of the Mississippi River.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina has 17 significant watersheds.

sentence: The five basins west of the Blue Ridge Mountains flow to the Gulf of Mexico, while the rest flow to the Atlantic Ocean.

name: north_carolina

name: north_carolina
sentence: Elevation above sea level is the main cause of temperature change throughout the state, the mountainous region being the coolest all year round.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The climate is also influenced by the Atlantic Ocean and the Gulf Stream, especially in the coastal plain.

name: north_carolina

sentence: The coastal plain represents an average of about 2.5 cm of snow or ice per year, and there may be no snow or ice for many years.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Atlantic Ocean has less influence on the climate of the Piedmont region, which has warmer summers and cooler winters than along the coast, although the average daily maximum is still less than 90°F (32°C) in most locations.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina experiences severe weather both in summer and winter, with the threat of hurricanes, tropical storms, heavy rains and floods.
