sentence: National Park Service Units include the Appalachian National Scenic Trail, Blue Ridge Drive, Cape Hatteras National Marine Shore, Cape Lookout National Marine Shore, Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site in Flat Rock, Fort Raleigh National Historic Site in Manteo, Smoky Great Mountains National Park, Guilford Courthouse National Military Park in Greensboro, Moores Creek National Battlefield near Currie in Pender County, Overmountain Victory National Historic Trail, Old Salem National Historic Site in Winston-Salem, Tears National Historic Trail and Wright Brothers National Monument in Kill Devil Hills.

name: north_carolina
sentence: National forests include the Uwharrie National Forest in central North Carolina, the Croatian National Forest in eastern North Carolina, the Pisgah National Forest in the western mountains and the Nantahala National Forest in the southwestern part of the state.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina has traditions in art, music and cuisine.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The non-profit arts and culture industry generates $1.2 billion in direct economic activity in North Carolina, supporting more than 43,600 full-time equivalent jobs and generating $119 million in revenues for local governments and the state of North Carolina.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina created the North Carolina Museum of Art as the first large museum collection in the country that was formed by state legislation and funding and continues to bring millions to the NC economy.

name: north_carolina
sentence: See also the list of museums in North Carolina.

name: north_carolina
sentence: One of the most famous arts communities in the state is Seagrove, the capital of the artisan pottery of the United States, where artisans create artisan pottery inspired by the same traditions that began in this community more than two hundred years ago.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina has a large number of outstanding jazz musicians, some of whom are among the most important in the history of the genre.

name: north_carolina
sentence: These include John Coltrane (Hamlet, High Point); Thelonious Monk (Rocky Mount); Billy Taylor (Greenville); Woody Shaw (Laurinburg); Lou Donaldson (Durham); Max Roach (Newland); Tal Farlow (Greensboro); Albert, Jimmy and Percy Heath (Wilmington); Nina Simone (Tryon); and Billy Strayhorn (Hillsborough).

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina is also famous for its tradition of ancient music, and many recordings were made in the early 20th century by folk-song collector Bascom Lamar Lunsford.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Musicians like North Carolina Ramblers helped solidify the sound of country music in the late 1920s, while influential musician bluegrass Doc Watson is also native to North Carolina.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina and South Carolina are home to traditional rural blues, especially the style known as the Piedmont blues.

sentence: Ben Folds Five is originally from Winston-Salem, and Ben Folds still records and resides in Chapel Hill.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Triangle Research region has long been a well-known centre for folk, rock, metal, jazz and punk.

name: north_carolina

name: north_carolina
sentence: Other famous musicians from North Carolina include J. Cole, Shirley Caesar, Roberta Flack, Clyde McPhatter, Nnenna Freelon, Warren Haynes, Jimmy Herring, Michael Houser, Eric Church, Future Islands, Randy Travis, Ryan Adams, Ronnie Milsap, Anthony Hamilton, The Avett Brothers and Luke Combs.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Metallic and punk pieces such as Corrosion of Conformity, Between the Buried and Me and Nightmare Sonata come from North Carolina.

sentence: Clay Aiken (season 2), Fantasia Barrino (season 3), Chris Daugherty (season 5), Kellie Pickler (season 5), Bucky Covington (season 5), Anoop Desai (season eight), Scotty McCreery (season ten) and Caleb Johnson (season thirteen).

sentence: North Carolina also has the most American idol winners with Barrino, McCreery, and Johnson.

name: north_carolina

Fletcher Opera Institute of the University of North Carolina School of the Arts in Winston-Salem, the Department of Music of the University of North Carolina in Chapel Hill and the UNC Greensboro.

name: north_carolina

name: north_carolina
sentence: A basic food from North Carolina is pork barbecue.

name: north_carolina
sentence: There are strong regional differences and rivalries on the sauces and methods used to make the barbecue.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The common trend in western North Carolina is the use of superior Boston buttocks.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Western North Carolina pork barbecue uses tomato-based sauce, and only pork shoulder (black meat) is used.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Western North Carolina barbecue is commonly referred to as Lexington BBQ after the town of Lexington Piedmont Triad, the Lexington Barbecue Festival home, which attracts more than 100,000 visitors each October.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The North Carolina Pork Barbecue uses vinegar and red pepper sauce and the "whole pig" is cooked, incorporating both white and dark meat.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Krispy Kreme, an international chain of donut shops, was founded in North Carolina; the company's headquarters are in Winston-Salem.

sentence: Pepsi-Cola was first produced in New Bern in 1898.

sentence: Cook Out, a popular fast food chain with hamburgers, hot dogs and milkshakes in a wide variety of flavors, was founded in Greensboro in 1989 and began to grow outside North Carolina.

sentence: In 2013, Southern Living named Durham–Chapel Hill the "most expensive city" of the South.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Over the past decade, North Carolina has become a cultural epicentre and a haven for internationally award-winning wines (Noni Bacca Winery), internationally-recognized cheeses (Ashe County), "International Institute for Gastronomic Arts: Conquer Yanks the Truffles, January 15, 2010" international hub for truffles (Garland Truffles) and beer manufacturing, since tobacco land has been converted into grape orchards, while state laws regulating volume alcohol (ABV) in beer have allowed a jump of six to fifteen percent.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Yadkin Valley in particular has become a market to strengthen grape production, while Asheville recently won the recognition of being named "Beer City USA".

name: north_carolina

name: north_carolina
sentence: The recognized and marketed beer brands in North Carolina include Highland Brewing, Duck Rabbit Brewery, Mother Earth Brewery, Weeping Radish Brewery, Big Boss Brewing, Foothills Brewing, Carolina Brewing Company, Lonerider Brewing and White Rabbit Brewing Company.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina has extensive pasture areas for beef and dairy cattle.

sentence: The truck farms are located in North Carolina.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Government's shipping, commercial fishing and softwood lumber industries are important to its economy.

sentence: Services industries, including education, health care, private research and retail, are also important.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Research Triangle Park, a large industrial complex in the Raleigh-Durham region, is one of the country's leading centres for electronics and medical research.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Tobacco was one of the first major industries to grow after the civil war.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Many farmers cultivated some tobacco, and the invention of cigarettes made the product particularly popular.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Winston-Salem was the birthplace of the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company (RJR), founded by R. J. Reynolds in 1874 as one of the city's sixteen tobacco companies.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In 1914, it sold 425 million packages of Camels per year.

name: north_carolina
sentence: RJR is an indirect wholly owned subsidiary of Reynolds American Inc., which in turn is 42% owned by British American Tobacco.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Several ships have been named according to the state, the most famous USNorth Carolina in the Pacific Ocean theatre of the Second World War.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Now disused, she's part of Wilmington's USNorth Carolina Battleship Memorial.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Another U.S. North Carolina nuclear attack submarine was commissioned in Wilmington on 3 May 2008.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Crown maintains a group of protected areas known as the North Carolina State Park System, which is managed by the North Carolina Division of Parks & Recreation (NCDPR), an agency of the North Carolina Department of Environment and Natural Resources (NCDENR).

name: north_carolina
sentence: Fort Bragg, near Fayetteville and Southern Pines, is a large and comprehensive military base and is the headquarters of the XVIIIth Airborne Corps, the 82nd Airborne Division and the Special Operations Command of the American Army.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The air wing of Fort Bragg is Pope Field, also near Fayetteville.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Located in Jacksonville, Marine Corps Base Camp Lejeune, combined with the nearby Marine Corps Air Station (MCAS) bases Cherry Point, MCAS New River, Camp Geiger, Camp Johnson, Stone Bay and Courthouse Bay, is the largest concentration of Marines and sailors in the world.

name: north_carolina
sentence: MCAS Cherry Point is home to 2 Maritime Aircraft Wing.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Located in Goldsboro, Air Force Base Seymour Johnson hosts 4 Wing Fighters and 916 Wing Air Refuelling.

name: north_carolina
sentence: One of the busiest U.S. Coast Guard air stations is located at the Coast Guard air station in Elizabeth City.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Sunny Point Southport Military Ocean Terminal is also stationed in North Carolina.

name: north_carolina
sentence: On January 24, 1961, a B-52G broke out in the open air and crashed after suffering a serious loss of fuel near Goldsboro, dropped two nuclear bombs in the process without detonation.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In 2013, it was revealed that three security mechanisms on a bomb had failed, leaving only one low-voltage switch preventing detonation.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota is a state of the Midwest of the United States.

name: north_dakota
sentence: It bears the names of the Amerindian tribes Lakota and Dakota Sioux, which constitute a large part of the population and historically dominate the territory.

name: north_dakota
sentence: It is the nineteenth largest in the region, the fourth least populated, and the fourth least populated of the 50 states.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Its capital is Bismarck, and its biggest city is Fargo.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota was admitted to the Union on 2 November 1889, as well as its neighbouring State, South Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: They were the 39th and 40th States admitted to the union.

name: north_dakota
sentence: President Benjamin Harrison changed the state documents before signing them so that no one would know who became a state first.

name: north_dakota
sentence: For ease of reference, both states are officially numbered in alphabetical order.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In the twenty-first century, the natural resources of North Dakota played a major role in its economic performance, particularly with the extraction of oil from the Bakken Formation, which is located under the north-western part of the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: This has led to population growth and a reduction in unemployment, resulting in North Dakota having the second lowest unemployment rate in the nation (after Hawaii).

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota is home to the highest artificial structure in the Western Hemisphere, the KVLY-TV mast.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota is located in the U.S. Upper Midwest region.

name: north_dakota
sentence: It is located in the middle of the North American continent and borders Canada to the north.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The geographic centre of North America is close to the city of Center.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Bismarck is the capital of North Dakota and Fargo is the largest city.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Soil is the most precious resource in North Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: It is the basis of the state's great agricultural wealth.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota also has enormous mineral resources.

name: north_dakota
sentence: These mineral resources include billions of tonnes of lignite coal.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In addition, North Dakota has large reserves of oil.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Oil was discovered in the state in 1951 and quickly became one of the most precious mineral resources in North Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In the early 2000s, the emergence of hydraulic fracturing technologies enabled mining companies to extract huge amounts of oil from the formation of Bakken shale rocks in the western part of the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The North Dakota economy is based more on agriculture than on most other states.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Many North Dakota plants process agricultural products or produce agricultural equipment.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Many state merchants also depend on agriculture.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Farms and ranches cover most of North Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: They stretch from the flat valley of the Red River to the east, through the hilly plains, to the rugged Badlands to the west.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The main crop, wheat, is grown in almost every county.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota harvests more than 90 per cent of Canada's canola and flaxseed.

name: north_dakota
sentence: It is also the leading national producer of barley and sunflower seeds and a leader in the production of beans, honey, lentils, oats, peas and sugar beets.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Few white settlers arrived in the North Dakota region before the 1870s because the railways had not yet entered the area.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In the early 1870s, the North Pacific Railway began crossing Dakota territory.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Large-scale agriculture also started in the 1870s.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Eastern societies and some families have established huge wheat farms covering vast tracts of land in the Red River valley.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The farms made huge profits which they were called Bonanza Farms.

name: north_dakota
sentence: White settlers, attracted by the success of Bonanza farms, flocked to North Dakota, rapidly increasing the territory's population.

name: north_dakota
sentence: By 1870, there were 2,405 people in North Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: By 1890 the population had increased to 190,983.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota was named for the Sioux people who once lived in the territory.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The Sioux were called Dakota or Lakota, which means allies or friends.

name: north_dakota
sentence: One of the nicknames in North Dakota is the Peace Garden State.

name: north_dakota
sentence: This nickname honours the International Garden of Peace, which is located on the state border with Manitoba, Canada.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota is also known as the state of Flickr because of the numerous land squirrels (Richardson land squirrels) that live in the central part of the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota is located in the American region known as Great Plains.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The state shares the Northern Red River with Minnesota in the east.

name: north_dakota
sentence: South Dakota is to the south, Montana to the west and the Canadian provinces of Saskatchewan and Manitoba to the north.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota is near the middle of North America with a stone marker in Rugby, North Dakota, which marks the "Geographic Centre of the North American Continent."

name: north_dakota
sentence: With an area of 70,762 square miles (183,273 km2), including 178,712 square kilometres, North Dakota is the 19th largest state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The western half of the state consists of the great hilly plains and the northern part of the Badlands, which are west of the Missouri River.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The highest point of the state, White Butte at 3506 feet (1,069 m), and Theodore Roosevelt National Park are in the Badlands.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The region is abundant in fossil fuels, including natural gas, crude oil, and lignite coal.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The Missouri River forms Sakakawea Lake, the third largest artificial lake in the United States, behind the Garrison Dam.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The central region of the state is divided into the Drift Prairie and Missouri Plateau.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The eastern part of the state consists of the flat valley of the Red River, the bottom of glacial lake Agassiz.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Its fertile soil, drained by the Red River that snakes north into Lake Winnipeg, supports a large agricultural industry.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Lake Devils, the largest natural lake in the state, is also to the east.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The majority of the state is covered by grasslands

name: north_dakota
sentence: Natural trees are usually found in North Dakota where there is good drainage, such as the ravines and valley near Pembina Gorge and Killdeer Mountains, Turtle Mountains, the hills around Devil Lake, in the dunes of McHenry County in central North Dakota, and along the slopes of the Sheyenne Valley and Sheyenne Delta.

name: north_dakota
sentence: This diverse land is home to almost 2,000 species of plants.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota has a continental climate with hot summers and cold winters.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Temperature differences are significant due to its remote interior position and being in the centre of the Northern Hemisphere, with distances approximately equal to the North Pole and the equator.

name: north_dakota
sentence: American Aboriginal peoples have lived in what is today North Dakota for thousands of years before the arrival of Europeans.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The known tribes included the Mandan people (around the 11th century), while the first Hidatsa group arrived a few hundred years later.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Both gathered in villages on the tributaries of the Missouri River in what would become the western centre of North Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Crow Indians travelled to the western plains to visit and trade with related Hidatas after the split, probably in the seventeenth century.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Later came the divisions of the Dakota people, Lakota, Santee and Yanktonai.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The Crees of Assiniboine and Plains made journeys southward towards the Indians of the village, either for trade or for war.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Shoshone Indians in current Wyoming and Montana may have carried out attacks on Indian enemies as far east as Missouri.

name: north_dakota
sentence: A group of Cheyennes lived in a village of land houses at the bottom of the Sheyenne River (site of Biesterfeldt) for decades in the 18th century.

name: north_dakota
sentence: As a result of the attacks by Cris, Assiniboines and Chippewas armed with firearms, they left the area around 1780 and crossed Missouri some time later.

name: north_dakota
sentence: A band of the few Indians of Sotaio lived east of the Missouri River and met the uprooted Cheyennes before the end of the century.

name: north_dakota
sentence: They soon followed the Cheyennes across Missouri and lived among them south of the Cannonball River.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Finally, the Cheyennes and the Sutaio became a tribe and transformed into buffalo hunters with ranges mainly outside North Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Before the mid-19th century, Arikara entered the future southern state and joined Mandan and Hidatsa.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Over time, a number of Indians have entered into treaties with the United States.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Many of the treaties define the territory of a particular tribe (see map).

name: north_dakota
sentence: The first European to reach the region was French-Canadian merchant Pierre Gaultier, Sieur de La Vérendrye, who led an exploration and trade team in the villages of Mandan in 1738.

name: north_dakota
sentence: From 1762 to 1802, the area was part of the Spanish Louisiana.

name: north_dakota
sentence: American Europeans did not settle in the Dakota territory until the end of the 19th century, when railways opened the area.

name: north_dakota
sentence: With the advantage of land concessions, they market their properties vigorously, exalting the region as the ideal for agriculture.

name: north_dakota
sentence: On February 22, 1889, during the administration of President Grover Cleveland, Congress passed an omnibus bill establishing a state for North Dakota, South Dakota, Montana and Washington.

name: north_dakota
sentence: His successor, Benjamin Harrison, signed the proclamations of official admission of North Dakota and South Dakota to the Union on November 2, 1889.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The rivalry between the two new States presented a dilemma that must first be admitted to exist.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Harrison ordered Secretary of State James G. Blaine to mix the papers and obscure him, which he signed first.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The order was not recorded, so no one knows which Dakotas were admitted first.

name: north_dakota
sentence: However, since North Dakota appears alphabetically in front of South Dakota, its proclamation was first published in the At Large Statutes.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The carelessness among wheat producers, particularly among Norwegian immigrants, led to a populist political movement centered in the non-partisan League ("NPL") at the time of the First World War.

name: north_dakota
sentence: NPL presented candidates on the Republican ticket (but merged into the Democratic Party after the Second World War).

name: north_dakota
sentence: He tried to isolate North Dakota from the power of banks and out-of-state corporations.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In addition to founding the Bank of North Dakota and North Dakota Mill and Elevator (both still exist), NPL established a state-owned railway line (later sold to Soo Line Railroad).

name: north_dakota
sentence: Anti-society laws virtually prohibited a company or bank from owning title to land delimited as agricultural land.

name: north_dakota
sentence: These laws, still in force today, after being confirmed by the state and federal courts, make it almost impossible to seize agricultural land, since even after the seizure, the title to property cannot be held by a bank or a mortgage company.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In addition, the North Dakota Bank, with powers similar to those of a federal reserve branch bank, exercised its power to limit the issuance of sub-prime mortgages and their guarantee in the form of derivative instruments, thus preventing the collapse of domestic housing prices following the 2008 financial crisis.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The original Capitol of the State of North Dakota at Bismarck burned on the ground on December 28, 1930.

name: north_dakota
sentence: It has been replaced by an art deco skyscraper with limestone facets that still stands today.

name: north_dakota
sentence: A series of federal investment and construction projects began in the 1950s, including the garrison dam and the bases of the Minot and Grand Forks Air Force.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Western North Dakota experienced a boom in oil exploration in the late 1970s and early 1980s, with rising oil prices making development profitable.

name: north_dakota
sentence: This boom ended after the drop in oil prices.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In recent years, the State has recorded unemployment rates below the national average and has increased employment and population growth.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Much of the growth was based on the development of Bakken's oil fields in the western part of the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Estimates of the remaining amount of oil in the region vary, some of which are estimated to be more than 100 years old.

name: north_dakota
sentence: For decades, the annual rate of North Dakota killings and the rate of violent crime were consistently lowest in the United States.

name: north_dakota
sentence: However, in recent years, although still below the national average, crime has risen sharply.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In 2016, the violent crime rate was three times higher than in 2004, with the increase occurring mostly in the late 2000s, coinciding with the oil boom era.

name: north_dakota
sentence: This happened at a time when the national violent crime rate decreased slightly.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Workers in the oil boom cities were blamed for much of the increase.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The U.S. Census Bureau estimates that the North Dakota population was 762,062 on July 1, 2019, an increase of 13.30 per cent from the 2010 U.S. Census.

name: north_dakota
sentence: This makes North Dakota the US state with the highest percentage of population growth since 2011.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota is the fourth least populous state in the country; only Alaska, Vermont and Wyoming have fewer residents.

name: north_dakota
sentence: With less than 2,000 people in 1870, the North Dakota population increased to nearly 680,000 by 1930.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Growth then slowed and the population fluctuated slightly over the past seven decades, reaching 617,761 at the 1970 census, of which 642,200 at the 2000 census.

name: north_dakota
sentence: With the exception of Amerindians, the North Dakota population has a lower percentage of minorities than that of the nation as a whole.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In 2011, 20.7 per cent of the North Dakota population under one year of age were minorities.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The population centre of North Dakota is located in Wells County, near Sykeston.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Note: The births in the table do not add up, because Hispanics are counted both by ethnicity and race, giving a higher overall number.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Throughout the second half of the 19th century and up to the beginning of the 20th century, North Dakota, as well as most of the Midwest, experienced a massive influx of newcomers from the eastern United States and immigrants from Europe.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota is a popular destination known to immigrant farmers and workers in general and their families, mainly from Norway, Iceland, Sweden, Germany and the United Kingdom.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Much of the colony was on the west side of the Red River Valley, as seen in South Dakota and parallel in Minnesota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: This region is well known for its fertile lands.

name: north_dakota
sentence: At the beginning of the First World War, it was one of the richest agricultural areas in North America.

name: north_dakota
sentence: But a period of higher rainfall ended, and many migrants failed in arid conditions.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Many of the family plots were too small to be successfully exploited.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Between the 1930s and the late 20th century, the North Dakota population gradually declined, interrupted by a few brief increases.

name: north_dakota

name: north_dakota
sentence: Throughout the history of the Amerindians, powwows were held, usually in spring, to rejoice at the beginning of the new life and the end of the winter cold.

sentence: Many pow-wows also had religious significance for some tribes.

sentence: Today, powwows are still part of Native culture and are frequented by both Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal people.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In North Dakota, the United Tribes International Powwow, held every month in September in the capital of Bismarck, is one of the largest powwows in the United States.

sentence: A pow wow is an opportunity for parades and Amerindian dancers in regalia, with many dance styles presented.

name: north_dakota
sentence: It is traditional for male dancers to wear regalia decorated with pearls, feathers and eagle feathers; male grass dancers wear coloured fringes, and fanciful male dancers wear vividly coloured feathers.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Fantasy dancers wear fabric, beaded moccasins and jewellery, while the jingle dancer wears a dress made of metal cones.

sentence: Intertribal dances during the pow-wow allow everyone (even the spectators) to participate in the dance.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The income tax structure of North Dakota is slightly progressive; the five tranches of government income tax rates are 1.1%, 2.04%, 2.27%, 2.64% and 2.90% in 2017.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In 2005, North Dakota ranked 22nd in terms of per capita taxes.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The sales tax in North Dakota is 5% for most items.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The state allows municipalities to introduce local sales taxes and special local taxes, such as the 1.75% additional sales tax in Grand Forks.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Excise taxes are levied on the purchase price or the market value of aircraft registered in North Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The Crown imposes a user tax on goods purchased elsewhere but used in North Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Property owners in North Dakota pay property taxes to their county, municipality, school district and special tax districts.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The Tax Foundation classifies North Dakota as the state with the 20th most favourable tax climate for businesses in the nation.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Tax Freedom Day arrives on April 1, 10 days earlier than National Tax Freedom Day.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In 2006, North Dakota was the lowest number of returns filed by taxpayers with adjusted gross income of more than $1 million, or only 333.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Of the 762,062 inhabitants of North Dakota, 56.54 per cent live in one of the fifteen most populated cities.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Fargo is the largest city in North Dakota and is the economic centre of the region.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Bismarck, in south-central North Dakota along the shores of Missouri, has been the capital of North Dakota since 1883, first as the capital of the Dakota Territory, then as the state capital since 1889.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Minot is a town in northern North Dakota and is home to North Dakota State Fair and Norsk Høstfest.

name: north_dakota
sentence: A few miles west of Bismarck, on the west side of the Missouri River, Mandan was named in honour of the Mandan Indians who lived in the area at the time of the Lewis and Clark Expedition.

name: north_dakota
sentence: New Salem is the site of the biggest statue of a holstein cow in the world

sentence: Grand Forks and Devils Lake are in picturesque areas of North Dakota.

sentence: West Fargo, North Dakota's fifth largest city, is one of the fastest growing cities.

sentence: Williston is near the confluence of the Missouri River and Yellowstone River near Montana.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Medora in North Dakota Badlands hosts the Medora Musical every summer and is the gateway to Theodore Roosevelt National Park.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Fort Yates, along the Missouri River on the Rock Indian Permanent Reserve, claims to be home to the last resting place for Hunkpa Lakota's leader Sitting Bull (Mobridge, South Dakota also claims his grave).

name: north_dakota
sentence: The state has 11 public colleges and universities, five tribal community colleges and four private schools.

name: north_dakota
sentence: "The Flickr State" is one of the nicknames of North Dakota and is derived from Richardson's terrestrial squirrel (Spermophilus richardson ii), a very common animal in the area.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The ground squirrel constantly travels its tail in a distinctive manner.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In 1953, legislation to make the land squirrel the emblem of the state was passed by the state legislature.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The state has 10 daily newspapers, the biggest being the Fargo-Moorhead Forum.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Other weekly and monthly publications (most of which are entirely supported by advertising) are also available.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The most important of these is the alternative weekly High Plains Reader.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The state's oldest radio station, WDAY-AM, was launched on 23 May 1922.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The three main radio markets in North Dakota are located around Fargo, Bismarck and Grand Forks, although stations broadcast in all regions of the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Several new stations were built at Williston in the early 2010s.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota has 34 AM and 88 FM radio stations.

name: north_dakota
sentence: KFGO in Fargo has the largest public.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Television broadcasting in North Dakota began on April 3, 1953, when KCJB-TV (now KXMC-TV) began operations in Minot.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota's television media markets are Fargo-Grand Forks (117th largest country), including half of the eastern state, and Minot-Bismarck (152nd) which make up the western half of the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: There are currently 31 full-power television stations distributed in 10 networks, with 17 digital sub-channels.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Public broadcasting in North Dakota is carried out by Prairie Public, with national television and radio networks affiliated with PBS and NPR.

sentence: Public television stations open for community programming are available on the cable networks of Bismarck, Dickinson, Fargo and Jamestown.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio is a state in the eastern Midwest of the United States of America.

name: ohio
sentence: Of the fifty states, it is the 34th largest by region, and with a population of nearly 11.7 million, is the seventh most populous and the tenth most densely populated.

name: ohio
sentence: The capital of the state and the largest city is Columbus, with the metropolitan area of Columbus, Grand Cincinnati and Grand Cleveland being the largest metropolitan areas.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio is bordered by Lake Erie to the north, Pennsylvania to the east, West Virginia to the southeast, Kentucky to the southwest, Indiana to the west and Michigan to the northwest.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio is historically known as "Buckeye State" after its Ohio buckeyes, and Ohions are also known as "Buckeyes".

name: ohio
sentence: The state derives its name from the Ohio River, whose name comes in turn from the word Senatorca ohi=yo', meaning "good river," "great river," or "great river."

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio was born from the lands west of Appalachia that were disputed from the colonial era through the Indian wars of the late 18th century.

name: ohio
sentence: It was separated from the resulting Northwest Territory, which was the first border of the new United States, and became the 17th State admitted to the Union on March 1, 1803, and the first under the North-West Ordinance.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio was the first free post-colonial state admitted to union, and became one of the first and most influential industrial power stations in the 20th century; although it has evolved to a more information- and service-oriented economy in the 21st century, Ohio remains an industrial state, ranking seventh in GDP in 2019, with the third largest manufacturing sector and second largest automotive production.

name: ohio
sentence: The government of Ohio is composed of the executive, led by the Governor; the legislature, composed of the Bicameral General Assembly of Ohio; and the judiciary, led by the Supreme Court of the State.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio holds 16 seats in the House of Representatives of the United States.

name: ohio
sentence: The State is known for its status as both a pivotal state and a gazebo in national elections.

name: ohio
sentence: Eight presidents of the United States came from Ohio, the most from any state, allowing him to receive the moniker "Mother of Presidents".

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio's geographic location has proven to be an asset for economic growth and expansion.

name: ohio
sentence: As Ohio connects the Northeast to the Midwest, many goods and business traffic cross its borders along its well-developed roads.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio has the country's 10th largest road network and is less than a day's drive away from 50 per cent of the North American population and 70 per cent of North America's manufacturing capacity.

name: ohio
sentence: To the north, Lake Erie gives Ohio 312 miles (502 km) of coastline, allowing many loading ports.

name: ohio
sentence: The southern Ohio border is defined by the Ohio River (the boundary being at the lower limit of 1792 on the north side of the river), and much of the northern boundary is defined by Lake Erie.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio's neighbours are Pennsylvania in the east, Michigan in the northwest, Lake Erie in the north, Indiana in the west, Kentucky in the south, and West Virginia in the southeast.

name: ohio
sentence: The Ohio boundaries were defined in the enabling legislation of 1802 as follows:

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio is bounded by the Ohio River, but most of the river itself belongs to Kentucky and West Virginia.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1980, the U.S. Supreme Court ruled that, based on the wording of Virginia's cessation of territory (which at the time included what is now Kentucky and West Virginia), the Ohio-Kentucky border (and consequently West Virginia) is the low north mark of the river as it existed in 1792.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio only has this part of the river between the low water mark of the 1792 river and the current high water mark.

name: ohio
sentence: The boundary with Michigan also changed, following the Toledo War, to slightly northeasterly to the north shore of the mouth of the Maumee River.

name: ohio
sentence: Much of Ohio has glacial till plains, with an exceptionally flat area in the northwest known as Great Black Swamp.

name: ohio
sentence: This glazed area of the north-west and central state is bordered first to the east and south-east by a belt known as the glazed Allegheny plateau, then by another belt known as the unglazed Allegheny plateau.

name: ohio
sentence: Most of Ohio is of low relief, but the Unglazed Allegheny Plateau has rugged hills and forests.

name: ohio
sentence: The rugged southeastern quadrant of Ohio, which extends into an arc-shaped arc along the Ohio River, from the western part of Virginia Panhandle to the outskirts of Cincinnati, forms a distinct socio-economic unit.

name: ohio
sentence: Geologically similar to parts of West Virginia and southwestern Pennsylvania, mining in that area, dependence on small pockets of former manufacturing facilities and the distinctive regional dialect put this section out of the rest of the state.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1965, the United States Congress passed the Appalachian Regional Development Act, an attempt to "respond to the persistent poverty and growing economic desperation of the Appalachian region".

name: ohio
sentence: This law defines 29 Ohio counties as part of Appalachia.

name: ohio
sentence: While 1/3 of Ohio's land mass is in the Appalachian region defined by the federal government, only 12.8% of Ohio's inhabitants live there (1.476 million people).

name: ohio
sentence: Important rivers in the state include the Cuyahoga River, the Great Miami River, the Maumee River, the Muskingum River and the Scioto River.

name: ohio
sentence: The rivers in the northern part of the state flow into the northern Atlantic Ocean via Lake Erie and the St. Lawrence River, and the rivers in the southern part of the state flow through the Gulf of Mexico via Ohio and then Mississippi.

name: ohio
sentence: The worst weather catastrophe in Ohio's history occurred along the Great Miami River in 1913.

name: ohio
sentence: Known as the Dayton Great Flood, the entire Miami River watershed has flooded, including the Dayton downtown business district.

name: ohio
sentence: As a result, the Miami Conservancy District was established as the first major floodplain engineering project in Ohio and the United States.

name: ohio
sentence: Great Lake St. Marys, in the western central part of the state, was built as a source of water for canals at the time of canal construction from 1820 to 1850.

name: ohio
sentence: For many years, this body of water, more than 52 km2, was the largest artificial lake in the world.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio canal projects were not the economic fiasco that similar efforts were made in other states.

name: ohio
sentence: Some cities, such as Dayton, owe their industrial emergence to their location on the canals, and until 1910 the inland canals carried a large portion of the state's bulk cargo.

name: ohio
sentence: The Ohio climate is a humid continental climate (Köppen Dfa/Dfb climate classification) in most of the state, except in the extreme southern counties of the Ohio Bluegrass region, which are located on the northern periphery of the subtropical humid climate (Cfa) and the U.S. Upland South region.

name: ohio
sentence: Summers are generally warm and humid throughout the state, while winters usually vary from cold to cold.

name: ohio
sentence: Precipitation in Ohio is moderate throughout the year.

name: ohio
sentence: Violent weather is not uncommon in the state, although there are generally fewer reports of tornadoes in Ohio than in states in what is known as the Tornado gangway.

name: ohio
sentence: Lake-effect snow storms are not uncommon on the southeast shore of Lake Erie, which is located in an area designated as the snow belt.

name: ohio
sentence: Although mainly not in a subtropical climate, warmer and more climatic flora and fauna reach Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: For example, some trees with more southern ranges, such as Blackjack oak, Quercus marilandica, are located northerly of Ohio, just north of the Ohio River.

name: ohio
sentence: Also referring to this climate transition from subtropical to continental climate, several plants such as southern magnolia (Magnolia grandiflora), Albizia julibrissin (mimosa), Crape Myrtle, and even occasionally Needle Palm are robust landscaping materials regularly used as street, yard and garden plantations in the Ohio Bluegrass area; but these same plants will simply not thrive in many of the rest of the state.

name: ohio
sentence: This interesting change can be observed by traveling across Ohio on Interstate 75 from Cincinnati to Toledo; the traveller observing this various state can even catch a glimpse of Cincinnati's common lizard, one of the few examples of permanent "subtropical" wildlife in Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: Due to flooding resulting in severely damaged roads, Governor Mike DeWine declared a state of emergency in 37 Ohio counties in 2019.

name: ohio
sentence: The highest recorded temperature was 113°F (45°C), near Gallipolis on 21 July 1934.

name: ohio
sentence: The lowest recorded temperature was −39 °F (−39 °C) at Milligan on 10 February 1899 during the Great Blizzard of 1899.

name: ohio
sentence: Although few individuals have registered as being visible to the average resident, more than 200 earthquakes with a magnitude of 2.0 or more have occurred in Ohio since 1776.

name: ohio
sentence: The seismic zone of western Ohio and part of the seismic zone of the Southern Great Lakes are located in the state, and there are numerous faults beneath the surface.

name: ohio
sentence: The largest known earthquake in Ohio's history was the Anna earthquake in Shelby County on March 9, 1937.

name: ohio
sentence: It was centered in western Ohio, with a magnitude of 5.4, and was VIII-intensity.

name: ohio
sentence: Other major earthquakes in Ohio include: one of magnitude 4.8 near Lima on September 19, 1884; one of magnitude 4.2 near Portsmouth on May 17, 1901; and one of 5.0 in LeRoy Township in Lake County on January 31, 1986, which continued to trigger 13 replicas of magnitude 0.5 to 2.4 for two months.

name: ohio
sentence: Significant earthquakes in Ohio in the 21st century included an earthquake on December 31, 2011, approximately 4 kilometres (2.5 mi) northwest of Youngstown, and an earthquake on June 10, 2019, about 5 kilometres (3.1 mi) northwest of Eastlake under Lake Erie.

name: ohio
sentence: Columbus is the capital of Ohio, located near the geographic center of the state and well known for Ohio State University.

name: ohio
sentence: However, other Ohio cities operate as economic and cultural centres in metropolitan areas.

name: ohio
sentence: Akron, Canton, Cleveland, Mansfield and Youngstown are in the northeast, known for the major industrial companies Goodyear Tire and Rubber and Timken, the top-ranked colleges Case Western Reserve University and Kent State University, the Cleveland Clinic, and cultural attractions including the Cleveland Art Museum, Big Five Group Cleveland Orchestra, Playhouse Square, the Pro Football Hall of Fame, and the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame.

name: ohio
sentence: Lima and Toledo are the main cities in northwestern Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: Northwestern Ohio is known for its glass industry and is home to Owens Corning and Owens-Illinois, two Fortune 500 companies.

name: ohio
sentence: Dayton and Springfield are located in the Miami Valley, home to Dayton University, the Dayton Ballet, and the large base of the Wright-Patterson Air Force.

name: ohio
sentence: Cincinnati anchors southwest Ohio and is the largest economy in the state.

name: ohio
sentence: It houses the University of Miami and the University of Cincinnati, Cincinnati Union Terminal, Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra, as well as various Fortune 500 companies including Procter & Gamble, Kroger, Macy's, Inc. and the fifth third bank.

name: ohio
sentence: Steubenville is the only metropolitan town in Appalachian Ohio, home to Hocking Hills National Park.

name: ohio
sentence: The Cincinnati metropolitan area extends as far as Kentucky and Indiana, the Steubenville metropolitan area extends as far as West Virginia, the Toledo metropolitan area extends as far as Michigan and the Youngstown metropolitan area extends as far as Pennsylvania.

name: ohio
sentence: Other metropolitan areas that are home to Ohio's cities include:

name: ohio
sentence: The cities of Ohio that serve as micropolitan centres in the United States include:

name: ohio
sentence: Archaeological evidence of spear points of the Folsom and Clovis types indicates that the Ohio Valley was inhabited by nomads as early as 13,000 B.C.

name: ohio
sentence: These first nomads disappeared from Ohio by 1000 B.C.

name: ohio
sentence: Between 1000 and 800 B.C., Adena's sedentary culture appeared.

name: ohio
sentence: The Adenas were able to establish "semi-permanent" villages because they domesticated plants, including sunflowers, and "wheat squash and possibly corn"; with hunting and gathering, this culture supported more established and complex villages.

name: ohio
sentence: The most remarkable remnant of Adena culture is the Grand Snake Mound, located in Adams County, Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: Around 100 B.C., Adena evolved to become the people of Hopewell who were also mound builders.

name: ohio
sentence: Their complex and technologically sophisticated works of earth can be found in Marietta, Newark and Circleville today.

name: ohio
sentence: They were also a prolific commercial company, with their commercial network covering one third of the continent.

name: ohio
sentence: Hopewell disappeared from the Ohio Valley about 600 AD.

name: ohio
sentence: The Mississippi culture developed with the decline of Hopewell culture.

name: ohio
sentence: Many people speaking the Siwan of the plains and the east coast claim them as ancestors and say that they lived throughout the Ohio region until about the 13th century.

name: ohio
sentence: There were three other contemporary cultures with the Mississippians: the ancient Fort people, the Whittlesey Focus people, and Monongahela culture.

name: ohio
sentence: The three cultures disappeared in the seventeenth century.

name: ohio
sentence: Their origins are not known.

name: ohio
sentence: The Shawnes may have absorbed the people of the Old Fort.

name: ohio
sentence: It is also possible that the Monongahela did not hold land in Ohio during the colonial era.

name: ohio
sentence: The culture of Mississippi was close and exchanged much with the people of the Old Fort.

name: ohio
sentence: The Indians of the Ohio Valley were greatly affected by the aggressive tactics of the Iroquois Confederation, based in central and western New York.

name: ohio
sentence: After the beaver wars in the mid-17th century, the Iroquois claimed much of Ohio as a hunting ground and, most importantly, as a beaver trap.

name: ohio
sentence: After the devastation of epidemics and war in the mid-17th century, which largely emptied the native country of Ohio in the mid-17th century to the end of the 17th century, the land gradually became repopulated by the mainly Algonquian.

name: ohio
sentence: Many of these Ohio nations were multi-ethnic (sometimes multi-lingual) societies born of the devastation caused by disease, war and subsequent social instability.

name: ohio
sentence: They were still in agriculture (maize, sunflowers, beans, etc.)

name: ohio
sentence: supplemented by seasonal hunting.

name: ohio
sentence: In the 18th century, they were part of a larger world economy created by Europe's entry into the fur trade.

name: ohio
sentence: Indigenous nations living in Ohio during the historical period included the Iroquoians, the Algonquians, and the Siwans.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio was also home to Indian massacres, such as the Yellow Creek massacre, the Gnadenhutten massacre and the Pontiac Rebellion School massacre.

name: ohio
sentence: Most of the Aboriginal people who remained in Ohio were gradually redeemed and persuaded to leave, or ordered by law, in the early 19th century with the Indian Abduction Act of 1830.

name: ohio
sentence: In the 18th century, the French introduced a system of trading posts to control the fur trade in the region.

name: ohio
sentence: From 1754 on, France and Britain fought the French and Indian wars.

name: ohio
sentence: Following the Treaty of Paris, the French gave control of Ohio and the rest of the Old North West to Great Britain.

name: ohio
sentence: In the Treaty of Paris of 1783, Britain ceded to the United States all the claims of the Ohio country.

name: ohio
sentence: The United States created the Northwest Territory under the North-West Order of 1787.

name: ohio
sentence: Slavery is not allowed in the new territory.

name: ohio
sentence: The settlement began with the founding of Marietta by the Ohio Company of Associates, which had been formed by a group of U.S. Revolutionary War veterans.

name: ohio
sentence: As a result of the Ohio Company, the Miami Company (also known as the "Purchase of Symmes") claimed the southwest section, and the Connecticut Land Company surveyed and established the Connecticut West Reserve in the present northeast of Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: Territorial surveyors at Fort Steuben began to survey approximately at the same time an area in eastern Ohio called Seven Ranges.

name: ohio
sentence: The former Northwest Territory originally included areas formerly known as Ohio Country and Illinois Country.

name: ohio
sentence: As Ohio was preparing to become a state, Indiana was created, which reduced the territory of the Northwest to about the present size of Ohio, plus half of the lower Michigan Peninsula and the eastern tip of the upper peninsula, as well as a portion of the southeast Indiana called "The Gore".

name: ohio
sentence: The coalition of Amerindian tribes, known as the Western Confederation, was forced to cede a vast territory, including much of the present Ohio, in the Treaty of Greenville in 1795.

name: ohio
sentence: Under the North-West Ordinance, areas could be defined and admitted as states as soon as their population reached 60,000.

name: ohio
sentence: Although the population of Ohio was only 45,000 in December 1801, Congress determined that it was growing rapidly and had already begun to become a state.

name: ohio
sentence: With regard to the natives of Leni Lenape, Congress decided that 10,000 acres on the Muskingum River in the present state of Ohio would be "separated and that their property would be vested in the Moravian Brothers [...] or a Society of the said Brothers for civilizing the Indians and promoting Christianity."

name: ohio
sentence: Rufus Putnam served extensively in the French and Indian wars and in the American Revolutionary War.

name: ohio
sentence: He was one of the most respected men in the early years of the US.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1776 Putnam created a method of building portable fortifications, which allowed the Continental Army to drive the British from Boston.

name: ohio
sentence: George Washington was so impressed that he turned Putnam into his chief engineer.

name: ohio
sentence: After the war, Putnam and Manasseh Cutler contributed to the creation of the Northwest Order, which opened the Northwest Territory for settlement.

name: ohio
sentence: This land served as a compensation for what was due to the veterans of the revolutionary war.

name: ohio
sentence: It is also on Putnam's recommendation that the lands be surveyed and arranged in six-square-mile townships.

name: ohio
sentence: Putnam organized and led the first group of ex-combatants in the territory.

name: ohio
sentence: They moved to Marietta, Ohio, where they built a great fort called Campus Martius.

name: ohio
sentence: Putnam and Cutler insisted that the Northwest Territory should be a free territory – no slavery.

name: ohio
sentence: They were both from Puritan New England, and the Puritans firmly believed that slavery was morally evil.

name: ohio
sentence: The Northwest Territory doubled the size of the United States, and it turned out that it was slavery-free in the decades that followed.

name: ohio
sentence: It includes what has become Ohio, Indiana, Illinois, Michigan, Wisconsin and part of Minnesota.

name: ohio
sentence: Had these States been slave states, and their electoral votes had been attributed to Abraham Lincoln's main competitor, Lincoln would not have been elected president.

name: ohio
sentence: Civil war would not have been fought.

name: ohio
sentence: And even if there had been a civil war, the North would probably have lost.

name: ohio
sentence: Putnam, in Puritan tradition, has played an important role in the establishment of education in the Northwest Territory.

name: ohio
sentence: Important lands have been set aside for schools.

name: ohio
sentence: Putnam had been one of the principal benefactors in the founding of the Leicester Academy in Massachusetts, and in 1798 he also created the plan for the construction of the Muskingum Academy (now Marietta College) in Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1780, the directors of the Ohio Company appointed him the Superintendent of all matters relating to the settlement north of the Ohio River.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1796 he was commissioned by President George Washington as surveyor general of the United States Lands.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1788 he was a judge at the First Court of the Northwest Territory.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1802 he served in the assembly to form a constitution for the state of Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: On February 19, 1803 U.S. President Thomas Jefferson signed a law of Congress that approved the limits and constitution of Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: However, Congress had never passed a resolution officially recognizing Ohio as the 17th state.

name: ohio
sentence: The current custom of Congress to declare an official date of the State did not begin until 1812, with the admission of Louisiana as the 18th state.

name: ohio
sentence: Although no formal admission resolution was required, when surveillance was discovered in 1953, while Ohio was preparing to celebrate its sesquicentenary, the Ohio MP, George H. Bender, introduced to Congress a bill to admit Ohio to the Union retroactively to March 1, 1803, when the Ohio General Assembly met for the first time.

name: ohio
sentence: At a special session in the former state capital in Chillicothe, the Ohio State Legislative Assembly approved a new petition for the creation of a state that was handed over to Washington, D.C., on horseback.

name: ohio
sentence: On August 7, 1953 (the year of Ohio's 150th anniversary), President Eisenhower signed a joint Congress resolution which officially declared March 1, 1803, the date Ohio entered the Union.

name: ohio
sentence: There are three capitals in Ohio: Chillicothe, Zanesville and Columbus.

name: ohio
sentence: Chillicothe was the capital between 1803 and 1810.

name: ohio
sentence: The capital was then moved to Zanesville for two years, as part of a state legislative compromise to pass a bill.

name: ohio
sentence: The capital was subsequently relocated to Chillicothe, which was the capital from 1812 to 1816.

name: ohio
sentence: Finally, the capital was moved to Columbus, to have it near the geographical center of the State.

name: ohio
sentence: Although many Amerindians migrated westward to escape the encroachment of the Americans, others remained in the state, sometimes partly assimilated.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1830, under the leadership of President Andrew Jackson, the U.S. government forced the kidnapping of most tribes in Indian territory west of Mississippi.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1835 Ohio fought with Michigan in the Toledo War, an essentially bloodless border war on the Toledo Strip.

name: ohio
sentence: Only one person was wounded in the conflict.

name: ohio
sentence: Congress intervened, making the admission of Michigan as a conditional state at the end of the conflict.

name: ohio
sentence: In exchange for the abandonment of its claim to the Toledo Band, Michigan received two-thirds west of the upper peninsula, in addition to a third east that was already considered part of the state.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio's central position and population gave it an important place during the civil war.

name: ohio
sentence: The Ohio River was a vital artery for troop and supply movements, as was the Ohio Railway.

name: ohio
sentence: The Ohio industry made the state one of the most important states in the Union during the civil war.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio provided more soldiers per capita than any other state in the Union.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1862, the state's morale was severely shaken as a result of the Battle of Shiloh, a costly victory in which Ohio forces suffered 2,000 casualties.

name: ohio
sentence: Later that year, when the Confederate troops under Stonewall Jackson threatened Washington, D.C., Ohio governor David Tod could still recruit 5,000 volunteers to provide three months of service.

name: ohio
sentence: From 12 to 23 July 1863, South Ohio and Indiana were attacked in Morgan's Raid.

name: ohio
sentence: While this raid was insignificant and small, it caused fear among the people of Ohio and Indiana.

name: ohio
sentence: Almost 35,000 Ohioans died in the conflict and 30,000 were physically injured.

name: ohio
sentence: At the end of the civil war, the Union's first three generals – Ulysses S. Grant, William Tecumseh Sherman and Philip Sheridan – all came from Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1912, a Constitutional Convention was held with Charles Burleigh Galbreath as secretary.

name: ohio
sentence: The outcome reflects the concerns of the progressive era.

name: ohio
sentence: He introduced the initiative and the referendum.

name: ohio
sentence: In addition, it allowed the General Assembly to ask questions about voting so that the people could ratify the laws and constitutional amendments emanating from the Legislative Assembly.

name: ohio
sentence: According to Jeffersonian's principle that laws should be reviewed once per generation, the Constitution provided that a recurring issue would appear on the ballots of the Ohio general election every 20 years.

name: ohio
sentence: The question arises whether a new convention is necessary.

name: ohio
sentence: Although the question appeared in 1932, 1952, 1972 and 1992, it was never approved.

name: ohio

sentence: Oklahoma is a state in the south-central United States, bordered by the state of Texas in the south and west, Kansas in the north, Missouri in the northeast, Arkansas in the east, New Mexico in the west, and Colorado in the northwest.

name: oklahoma
sentence: It is also known informally by its nickname, "The Sooner State", with reference to non-Aboriginal settlers who staked their land claims prior to the official land opening date in western Oklahoma or prior to the Indian Credit Act of 1889, which increased Euro-American settlement in eastern Indian territory.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The name Oklahoma comes from the language phrase of Choctaw okla humma, literally meaning the red people.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Equivalent to the Indian English word, okla humma was a sentence in the language of Choctaw that described the Amerindians as a whole.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma later became the de facto name of Oklahoma territory, and it was officially approved in 1890, two years after the area was opened to white settlers.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In the Chickasaw language, the state is known as Oklahomma', in Arapaho as bo'oobe' (literally meaning red earth), Pawnee: Uukhuúwa, and Cayuga: Gahnawiyo.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma is the 20th state of the United States, covering an area of 69,899 square miles (181,040 km2), with 68,595 square miles (177.660 km2) of land and 1,304 square miles (3,380 km2) of water.

name: oklahoma
sentence: It is found in part in the Great Plains near the geographic center of the 48 contiguous states.

name: oklahoma
sentence: It is bounded to the east by Arkansas and Missouri, to the north by Kansas, to the north-west by Colorado, to the extreme west by New Mexico, and to the south and near-west by Texas.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The Oklahoma is located between the Great Plains and the Ozark Plateau in the Gulf of Mexico watershed, generally sloping from the high plains of its western boundary to the low wetlands of its southeast boundary.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Its highest and lowest points follow this trend, with its highest peak, Black Mesa, 4,973 feet (1,516 m) above sea level, located near its very northwest corner in the Oklahoma Panhandle.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The lowest point in the state is on the Little River, close to its southeast boundary, near the town of Idabel, which descends 289 feet (88 m) above sea level.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Among the most geographically diverse states, Oklahoma is one of four to house more than 10 distinct ecological regions, with 11 within its borders – more per square mile than in any other state.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Its western and eastern halves, however, are marked by extreme differences in geographic diversity: the eastern Oklahoma affects eight ecological regions and its western half contains three.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Although having fewer ecological areas Western Oklahoma contains many rare, relic species.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma has four main mountain ranges: Ouachita Mountains, Arbuckle Mountains, Wichita Mountains, and Ozark Mountains.

name: oklahoma

name: oklahoma
sentence: More than 500 streams and rivers are the rivers of Oklahoma, and with 200 lakes created by dams, it holds the largest number of artificial reservoirs in the country.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The majority of the state is located in two primary drainage basins belonging to the Red and Arkansas rivers, although the Lee and Little rivers also contain important drainage basins.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Due to the location of Oklahoma at the confluence of many geographic regions, the state's climate regions have a high rate of biodiversity.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Forests cover 24% of Oklahoma grasslands and grasslands composed of short-grass, mixed-grass, and high-grass grasslands, which are home to extensive ecosystems in central and western parts of the state, although cultivated land has largely replaced native grasses.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Where precipitation is scattered in the western regions of the state, short-grass prairies and shrubs are the most important ecosystems, although pine pine pines, red cedars (junipers) and ponderosa pines grow near rivers and creek beds in the western panhandle.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The southwestern Oklahoma contains many rare and isolated species, including sugar maple, bigtooth maple, nolina, and live Texas oak.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Marshes, cypress forests and mixes of short-leaved pines, lobolly pines, blue palms and deciduous forests dominate the southeast quarter of the state, while mixtures of oaks, elms, red cedars (Juniperus virginiana) and pine forests cover the northeast of Oklahoma.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The state is home to populations of white-tailed deer, mule deer, antelope, coyotes, mountain lions, bobcats, elk, and birds such as quail, doves, cardinals, bald eagles, red-tailed hawks and pheasants.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In prairie ecosystems, American bison, large prairie chickens, badgers, and armadillos are common, and some of the country's largest prairie dog cities inhabit short-grass prairies in the state panhandle.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Cross Timbers, a region from prairie to central Oklahoma forest, is home to 351 species of vertebrates.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Ouachita Mountains are home to populations of black bears, red foxes, grey foxes and river otters, which coexist with 328 vertebrate species in southeastern Oklahoma.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In addition, in the southeast of Oklahoma lives the American alligator.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma has fifty-one state parks, six national parks or protected areas, two national protected forests or grasslands, and a system of wildlife reserves and conservation areas.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Six per cent of the 10 million acres of state forest (40,000 km2) are public lands, including the western parts of the Ouachita National Forest, the largest and oldest national forest in the southern United States.

name: oklahoma
sentence: With 39,000 acres (160 km2), the Tallgrass Prairie Reserve in the north-central Oklahoma is the largest protected area of tall grass prairie in the world and is part of an ecosystem that covers only ten per cent of its former land area, once covering fourteen states.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In addition, Black Kettle National Prairie covers 31,300 acres (127 km2) of prairie in southwestern Oklahoma.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The Wichita Mountains Wildlife Refuge is the oldest and largest of nine national wildlife refuges in the state and was founded in 1901, covering 59,020 acres (238.8 km2).

name: oklahoma
sentence: Of the parks or recreation sites protected by the federal government of Oklahoma, the Chickasaw National Recreation Area is the largest, with 9,898.63 acres (40.0583 km2).

name: oklahoma
sentence: Other sites include the Santa Fe and Trail of Tears National Historic Trails, Fort Smith and Washita Battlefield National Historic Sites, and Oklahoma National Memorial.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma is in a humid subtropical region.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma occurs in a transition zone from semi-arid to the west, wet continental to the north, and wet subtropical to the east and south-east.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Most of the state is located in an area known as the Allée de Tornado, characterized by frequent interaction between cold and dry air in Canada, hot hot air, dry air in Mexico and the southwestern United States, and warm and wet air in the Gulf of Mexico.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Interactions between these three contrasting air currents produce severe weather (serious thunderstorms, damaging thunderstorm winds, large hail and tornadoes) with an almost invisible frequency anywhere else on planet Earth.

name: oklahoma
sentence: On average, 62 tornadoes hit the State per year, one of the highest rates in the world.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Due to the position of Oklahoma between zones of different temperatures and winds, weather conditions within the state can vary considerably over relatively short distances, and can change dramatically in a short time.

name: oklahoma
sentence: On November 11, 1911, the temperature in Oklahoma City reached 83°F (28°C) (the record for this date), then a cold front of unprecedented intensity slammed through the state, causing the temperature to reach 17°F (−8°C) (the record for this date) at midnight.

name: oklahoma
sentence: This type of phenomenon is also responsible for many tornadoes in the region, such as the Oklahoma tornado epidemic in 1912 when a warm front ran through a frozen cold front, resulting in an average of one tornado per hour.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The humid subtropical climate (Koppen Cfa) of central, southern and eastern Oklahoma is strongly influenced by southerly winds bringing moisture to the Gulf of Mexico.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Traveling westward, climate transitions to a semi-arid area (Koppen BSk) in the Panhandle High Plains and other areas west of Lawton to the west, less frequently affected by southerly moisture.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Precipitation and temperatures are decreasing from east to west as a result, with areas of the southeast having an average annual temperature of 62°F (17°C) and annual precipitation of more than 40" (1,020 mm) and up to 56" (1,420 mm), while areas of the panhandle (upper elevation) have an average of 58°F (14°C), with annual precipitation of less than 17" (430 mm).

name: oklahoma
sentence: Over almost all of Oklahoma, winter is the driest season.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Average monthly precipitation increases significantly in the spring to peak in May, the wettest month in most of the state, with its frequent and uncommon stormy activity.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Early June may still be wet, but most years see a marked decrease in precipitation in June and early July.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Mid-summer (July and August) represents a secondary dry season over much of Oklahoma, with long periods of hot weather with only sporadic stormy activity not uncommon for many years.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Severe drought is common in the warmest summers, such as those of 1934, 1954, 1980 and 2011, all of which experienced weeks at the end of the absence of virtual rain and peaks well above 100°F (38°C).

name: oklahoma
sentence: Average precipitation increased again from September to mid-October, representing a more humid secondary season, and then decreased from late October to December.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The whole state often has temperatures above 100°F (38°C) or below 0°F (−18°C), although temperatures below zero are rare in south-central and south-eastern Oklahoma.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Snowfall ranges from an average of less than 4 in (102 mm) in the south to just over 20 in (508 mm) at the Colorado border in the panhandle.

sentence: Oklahoma has also a rich African-American history.

name: oklahoma

name: oklahoma

sentence: With an education system consisting of public school districts and independent private institutions, Oklahoma had 638,817 students enrolled in 1,845 public primary, secondary and vocational schools in 533 school districts in 2008.

name: oklahoma

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma is placed in the South by the United States Census Bureau, but other definitions place the state at least in part in the Southwest, Midwest, Upland South and Great Plains.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The Oklahomans have a high rate of English, Scottish-Irish, German and Amerindian ancestry, with 25 different native languages spoken.

sentence: Western breeders, Amerindian tribes, southern settlers and eastern oil barons have shaped the state's cultural predisposition, and its largest cities have been named among the most under-estimated cultural destinations in the United States.

sentence: In the largest urban areas of the state, pockets of jazz culture thrive, and American Amerindian, Mexican and Asian communities produce music and art from their respective cultures.

sentence: Rodeos are popular throughout the state, and Guymon, in the panhandle of the state, welcomes one of the largest in the nation.

sentence: Oklahoma was the 21st recipient of federal government medical funding in 2005, with federal spending on health in the state totalling $75,801,364; immunizations, bioterrorism preparedness and health education were the top three most funded medical items.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Cases of major diseases are close to the national average in Oklahoma, and the state ranks at or slightly above the rest of the country as a percentage of people suffering from asthma, diabetes, cancer and hypertension.

name: oklahoma
