name: oklahoma
sentence: Residents of Oklahoma have lower than average life expectancy compared to many other states.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In 2014, men in Oklahoma lived on average 73.7 years compared to a national average of 76.7 years, and women lived on average 78.5 years compared to a national average of 81.5 years.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In addition, the increase in life expectancy was lower than the national average.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Men's life expectancy in Oklahoma between 1980 and 2014 increased by an average of 4.0 years, compared to a national average of 6.7 years increase in men's life expectancy.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Women's life expectancy in Oklahoma between 1980 and 2014 increased by 1.0 years compared to a national average of 4.0 years of increasing women's life expectancy.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Using 2016-2018 data, the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation calculated that life expectancy in Oklahoma counties ranged from 71.2 years for Okfuskee County to 79.7 years for Cimarron and Logan Counties.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The life expectancy for the entire state was 76.0 years.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma City and Tulsa are the 45th and 61st largest media markets in the United States, classified by Nielsen Media Research.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The third state media market, Lawton-Wichita Falls, Texas, is ranked 149th nationally by the Agency.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Television started in Oklahoma in 1949 when KFOR-TV (then WKY-TV) in Oklahoma City and KOTV-TV in Tulsa began broadcasting a few months apart.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Currently, all major U.S. broadcasting networks have affiliated television stations in the State.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The State has two main newspapers.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma City-based Oklahoman is the largest newspaper in the state and the 54th largest in the nation by broadcast, with a weekly readership of 138,493 and a Sunday readership of 202,690.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The Tulsa World, the second largest newspaper in Oklahoma and the 79th in the nation, has a Sunday broadcast of 132,969 and a daily readership of 93,558.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma's first newspaper was created in 1844, called the Cherokee Advocate, and was written both in Cherokee and English.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In 2006, there were more than 220 newspapers in the State, 177 with weekly publications and 48 with daily publications.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The first state radio station, WKY in Oklahoma City, started broadcasting in 1920.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In 2006, there were over 500 radio stations in Oklahoma with various local or national networks.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Five universities in Oklahoma operate public non-commercial radio stations/networks.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma has a few ethnic television channels that broadcast in Spanish and Asian, and there is some Amerindian programming.

name: oklahoma
sentence: TBN, a Christian religious television channel, had a studio in Tulsa, and built its first wholly owned subsidiary of TBN in Oklahoma City in 1980.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Transportation in Oklahoma is generated by an anchoring system for interstate highways, intercity rail lines, airports, inland ports and public transport networks.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Located along an integral point in the U.S. interstate network, the Oklahoma contains three interstate main highways and four interstate auxiliary highways.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In Oklahoma City, Interstate 35 interstates with Interstate 44 and Interstate 40, one of the most important intersections along the U.S. road network.

name: oklahoma
sentence: More than 12,000 miles (19,000 km) of roads constitute the largest road skeleton in the state, including government-operated roads, ten tolls or major toll roads, and the longest section of Highway 66 in the nation.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In 2008, Interstate 44 in Oklahoma City was Oklahoma's busiest highway, with a daily traffic volume of 123,300 cars.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In 2010, the state had the third largest number of bridges classified as structurally deficient, with nearly 5,212 bridges in poor condition, including 235 bridges in the national road network.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma's largest commercial airport is the Will Rogers World Airport in Oklahoma City, with an annual average of more than 3.5 million passengers (1.7 million boardings) in 2010.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Tulsa International Airport, the second largest commercial airport in the state, served more than 1.3 million boardings in 2010.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Between the two, six airlines operate in Oklahoma.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In terms of traffic, the R. L. Jones Jr. (Riverside) airport in Tulsa is the busiest airport in the state, with 335,826 take-offs and landings in 2008.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma has more than 150 public airports.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma is connected to the national rail network via Amtrak's Heartland Flyer, its only regional passenger transport line.

name: oklahoma
sentence: It is currently extending from Oklahoma City to Fort Worth, Texas, although legislators began seeking funding in early 2007 to link the Heartland Flyer to Tulsa.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Two inland ports on rivers serve Oklahoma: the port of Muskogee and the port of Tulsa de Catoosa.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The port of Tulsa de Catoosa is one of the most inland international ports in the United States, at the head of the navigational system of the McClellan–Kerr Arkansas River, which connects the barge traffic of Tulsa and Muskogee to the Mississippi River.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The port ships more than two million tons of goods per year and is a designated foreign trade area.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma is a constitutional republic with a government inspired by the U.S. federal government, with executive, legislative and judicial powers.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The State has 77 counties with jurisdiction over most of the local government functions in each area, five districts of Congress, and a plurality voting base within the Republican Party.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The representatives of the State are elected by pluralist vote in the State of Oklahoma.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma has the death penalty as a legal penalty, and the state had (between 1976 and mid-2011) the highest per capita execution rate in the nation.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The Legislative Assembly of Oklahoma is composed of the Senate and the House of Representatives.

name: oklahoma
sentence: As the legislative branch of the state government, it is responsible for collecting and distributing the funds needed to manage the government.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The honourable senator has 48 members for a four-year term, while the House has 101 members for a two-year term.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The State has a statutory term limit which limits any person to 12 cumulative years of service between the two legislative branches.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The judiciary of Oklahoma consists of the Supreme Court of Oklahoma, the Criminal Appeal Court of Oklahoma and 77 district courts, each serving a county.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The judiciary of Oklahoma also comprises two independent courts: an indictment court and the Oklahoma court on the judiciary.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The Oklahoma has two courts of last resort: the Supreme Court of the State hears civil cases and the State Criminal Court of Appeal hears criminal cases (this split system exists only in Oklahoma and nearby Texas).

name: oklahoma
sentence: The judges of these two courts, as well as the Court of Civil Appeal, are appointed by the Governor on the recommendation of the State Judicial Nominations Commission and are subject to a non-partisan loyalty vote on a six-year rotational schedule.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The executive is composed of the Governor, his staff and other elected officials.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Chief Leader of the Government, the Governor is the head of the Oklahoma Executive, who is the Commander-in-Chief of the Oklahoma National Guard when he is not called for federal use and reserves the power of veto to bills passed by the Legislative Assembly.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The executive branch's responsibilities include the submission of the budget, the enforcement of State laws and the preservation of peace within the State.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The state is divided into 77 local counties, each headed by a three-member council of elected commissioners, a tax assessor, a clerk, a clerk, a treasurer and a sheriff.

name: oklahoma
sentence: While each municipality operates as a separate and independent local government with executive, legislative and judicial powers, county governments retain jurisdiction over incorporated cities and unincorporated areas within their borders, but have an executive but no legislative or judicial power.

name: oklahoma
sentence: County and municipal governments collect taxes, employ a separate police force, organize elections and manage emergency response services under their jurisdiction.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Other local governments include school districts, technology centre districts, community college districts, rural fire departments, rural water districts and other special-purpose districts.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Thirty-nine Amerindian tribal governments are based in Oklahoma, each with limited authority in designated areas.

name: oklahoma
sentence: While typical Indian reserves in most of the United States are not present in Oklahoma, tribal governments hold land granted during the time of Indian territory, but with limited jurisdiction and no control over State governing bodies such as municipalities and counties.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Tribal governments are recognized by the United States as quasi-sovereign entities with executive, judicial and legislative powers over tribal members and functions, but are subject to the power of the United States Congress to revoke or refuse certain powers.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Tribal governments are required to submit a constitution and any subsequent amendment to the United States Congress for approval.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma has 11 sub-State districts, including the two major government councils, INCOG in Tulsa (Council of Indian Governments) and ACOG (Association of Central Oklahoma Governments).

name: oklahoma
sentence: During the first half-century of the state, Oklahoma was considered a democratic bastion, being carried by the Republican Party in only two presidential elections (1920 and 1928).

name: oklahoma
sentence: After the 1948 election, the state became firmly republican.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Although the registered Republicans were a minority in the state until 2015, Oklahoma was carried by Republican presidential candidates in all but one election since 1952: Lyndon B. Johnson's 1964 victory shaken.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Every county in Oklahoma has been won by Republican candidates in presidential elections since 2004.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In general, the Republicans are the strongest in the suburbs of Oklahoma City and Tulsa, as well as in the Panhandle.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The Democrats are the strongest in the eastern part of the state and Little Dixie, as well as the most Afro-American and internal parts of Oklahoma City and Tulsa.

name: oklahoma
sentence: With a population of 8.6% of Amerindians in the state, it is also interesting to note that most Amerindian constituencies vote Democratic in the margin exceeded only by African Americans.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Following the 2000 census, the delegation of Oklahoma to the United States House of Representatives was reduced from six to five representatives, each serving a district of Congress.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In the current Congress, the Republicans include the entire delegation of Oklahoma.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The Oklahoma had 598 places incorporated in 2010, including four cities with more than 100,000 inhabitants and 43 with more than 10,000 inhabitants.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Two of the 50 largest cities in the United States are Oklahoma, Oklahoma City and Tulsa, and 65% of Oklahomans live in their metropolitan areas, or spheres of economic and social influence defined by the United States Census Bureau as a metropolitan statistical area.

name: oklahoma

sentence: Although it has the highest overall Catholic percentage of all states, none of Rhode Island's counties ranks among the 10 most Catholic in the United States, as Catholics are very evenly distributed throughout the state.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The Jewish community of Rhode Island was centered in the Providence region, and emerged during a wave of Jewish immigration mainly from the Shtetls of Eastern Europe between 1880 and 1920.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The presence of the Synagogue Touro in Newport, the oldest synagogue in the United States, points out that these second wave immigrants did not create the first Jewish community on Rhode Island; a relatively smaller wave of Spanish and Portuguese Jews immigrated to Newport during the colonial era.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Rhode Island is divided into five counties, but it has no county government.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The entire State is divided into municipalities, which deal with all the affairs of the local government.

name: rhode_island
sentence: There are 39 cities on Rhode Island.

sentence: Rhode Island's economy had a colonial base in fishing.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The Blackstone River Valley was a major contributor to the American industrial revolution.

name: rhode_island
sentence: It was at Pawtucket that Samuel Slater set up Slater Mill in 1793, using the power of the Blackstone River to power his cotton mill.

name: rhode_island
sentence: For a while Rhode Island was one of the leaders in textiles.

name: rhode_island
sentence: However, with the Great Depression, most textile factories have moved to the southern states of the United States.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The textile industry is still part of the Rhode Island economy, but does not have the same power as before.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Other important industries in Rhode Island's past included the manufacture of tools, costume jewelry and silverware.

name: rhode_island
sentence: An interesting by-product of Rhode Island's industrial history is the number of abandoned plants, many of which are now used for condominiums, museums, offices and low-income homes.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Today, much of Rhode Island's economy is based on services, especially health care and education, and still to some extent manufacturing.

sentence: The state's nautical history continues in the twenty-first century in the form of the construction of nuclear submarines.

sentence: Rhode Island has the lowest level of per capita energy consumption in any state.

sentence: Rhode Island's taxes were significantly higher than those of neighbouring states because Rhode Island's income tax was based on 25% of the federal payment of the payer's income tax.

sentence: Former Governor Donald Carcieri stated that the higher tax rate had an inhibitory effect on corporate growth in the state and called for reductions to increase the competitiveness of the state's business environment.

sentence: At the beginning of the twentieth century, millions of American Africans left South Carolina and other southern states for jobs, opportunities and relative freedom in American cities outside the former Confederate states.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In total, from 1910 to 1970, 6.5 million Blacks left the South in the Great Migration.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In 1930 South Carolina had a white majority population for the first time since 1708.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina was one of several states that initially rejected the 19th Amendment (1920) giving women the right to vote.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The South Carolina legislature then ratified the amendment on 1 July 1969.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The civil rights movement's struggle took place in South Carolina as in other states of the South.

name: south_carolina
sentence: However, South Carolina has experienced a much less violent movement than other southern states.

name: south_carolina
sentence: This quiet transition from a Jim Crow company occurred because the white and black leaders of the state were willing to accept the slow change rather than being totally reluctant to accept change.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Other Southern Carolinians, like Senator Strom Thurmond, on the other hand, were among the most radical and effective opponents of social equality and integration in the nation.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In 2015, South Carolina had one of the lowest percentages among all women's states in the state legislature, at 13.5% (only Louisiana, Oklahoma and Wyoming had a lower percentage; the national average was 24.3%; the highest percentage was in Colorado at 41%).

name: south_carolina
sentence: In 2011, South Carolina ranked first in the country in terms of the rate of women killed by men.

name: south_carolina
sentence: As the 21st century progressed, South Carolina attracted new businesses with a 5% corporate income tax rate, no state property tax, no local income tax, no inventory tax, no sales tax on manufacturing equipment, industrial energy or materials for finished products, no wholesale tax and no unit tax on global profits.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina was one of the first states to stop paying for "early" baby deliveries, under Medicaid and private insurance.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The term "early elective" is defined as an induction of work or a section of the caesarean section between 37 and 39 weeks which is not medically based.

name: south_carolina
sentence: This change is intended to improve the health of babies and reduce unnecessary costs for South Carolina.

name: south_carolina
sentence: On 20 November 2014, South Carolina became the 35th state to legalize same-sex marriages, when a federal court ordered the change.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina has many venues for visual and performing arts.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The Gibbes Museum of Art in Charleston, the Greenville County Museum of Art, the Columbia Museum of Art, the Spartanburg Art Museum and the South Carolina State Museum in Columbia, among others, provide access to the state's visual arts.

name: south_carolina
sentence: There are also many historical sites and museums scattered throughout the state that pay tribute to many events and periods in the history of the state, from Amerindian housing to the present day.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina also has art rooms such as the Peace Center in Greenville, the Koger Center for the Arts in Columbia, and the Newberry Opera House, among others, to attract local, national and international talent to South Carolina.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Several major venues can host major events, including Colonial Life Arena in Columbia, Bon Secours Wellness Arena in Greenville, and North Charleston Coliseum.

name: south_carolina
sentence: One of the country's leading performing arts festivals, the Spoleto Festival USA, is held annually in Charleston.

name: south_carolina
sentence: There are also countless local festivals across the state highlighting numerous cultural traditions, historical events and folklore.

name: south_carolina
sentence: According to the South Carolina Arts Commission, creative industries generate $9.2 billion a year and support over 78,000 jobs in the state.

name: south_carolina
sentence: A 2009 government-wide survey by the University of South Carolina's Institute for Public Service and Policy Research found that 67% of residents had participated in the arts in some form in the past year and that, on average, citizens had participated in the arts 14 times in the previous year.

name: south_carolina
sentence: According to the Association of Religion Data Archives (ARDA), in 2010, the largest religion was Christianity, the largest denominations of which were the Southern Baptist Convention with 913,763 adherents, the Methodist Church united with 274,111 adherents, and the Roman Catholic Church with 181,743 adherents.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The fourth largest is the African Methodist Episcopal Church with 564 congregations and 121,000 members, and the fifth largest is the Presbyterian Church (USA) with 320 congregations and nearly 100,000 members.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In 2010, South Carolina was the US state with the highest per capita proportion of citizens following the Bahá'í Faith, with 17,559 adherents, making Bahá'í the second religion of the state.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Although no major professional sports team is based in South Carolina, the Caroline Panthers have training facilities in the state and played their home games from the inaugural season at Memorial Stadium in Clemson, however, they now play at Bank of America Stadium in North Carolina.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The Panthers consider themselves "the Carolines team" and refrain from naming themselves after Charlotte or either of the Carolinas.

sentence: The state is also home to many professional teams of minor leagues.

sentence: The College's teams represent their particular institutions in South Carolina, and are the main options for football, basketball and baseball participation in the state.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina is also a destination of choice for golf and water sports.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina is also home to one of NASCAR's first runways and its first paved highway, Darlington Raceway, northwest of Florence.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina's GDP in 2019 was $249.9 billion, making the state the 26th largest of GDP in the United States.

name: south_carolina
sentence: According to the United States Bureau of Economic Analysis, South Carolina's gross domestic product (GDP) stood at $97 billion in 1997 and $153 billion in 2007.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Its real per capita gross domestic product (GDP) in 2000 dollars was $26,772 in 1997 and $28,894 in 2007; it represented 85% of real GDP per capita of $31,619 for the United States in 1997 and 76% of the $38,020 for the United States in 2007.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The government's 2012 debt was calculated by source at $22.9 billion, or $7,800 per taxpayer.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Industrial products include textiles, chemicals, paper products, machinery, automobiles, automobiles and tourism.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The Government's main agricultural products are tobacco, poultry, cotton, livestock, dairy products, soybeans, hay, rice and pork.

name: south_carolina
sentence: According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, as of March 2012, South Carolina had 1,852,700 non-agricultural jobs, including 12 per cent in manufacturing, 11.5 per cent in leisure and hospitality, 19 per cent in trade, transport and public services, and 11.8 per cent in education and health services.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The services sector accounts for 83.7% of South Carolina's economy.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Many large corporations have moved to South Carolina.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Boeing opened an aircraft manufacturing plant in Charleston in 2011, which is one of the last two assembly sites of the 787 Dreamliner.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina is a state of the right to work and many companies use recruitment agencies to temporarily fill jobs.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Domtar in Rock Hill is the only Fortune 500 company based in South Carolina.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The Fortune 1000 list includes SCANA, Sonoco Products and ScanSource.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina is also benefiting from foreign investment.

name: south_carolina
sentence: There are 1,950 foreign companies in South Carolina employing nearly 135,000 people.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Foreign direct investment (FDI) contributed $1.06 billion to the state economy in 2010.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Since 1994, BMW has owned a production plant in Spartanburg County near Greer and since 1996 the Zapp Group has operated in Summerville near Charleston.

name: south_carolina
sentence: There are 36 television channels (including PBS affiliates) serving South Carolina with terrestrial access, and some on-line streaming.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The markets where the stations are located include Columbia, Florence, Allendale, Myrtle Beach, Greenville, Charleston, Conway, Beaufort, Hardeeville, Spartanburg, Greenwood, Anderson and Sumter.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The State has the fourth largest state system in the country, consisting of 11 interstates, numbered highways, public highways and secondary roads, for a total of about 41,500 miles.

name: south_carolina
sentence: On secondary roads, South Carolina uses a numbering system to follow all non-interstate and primary roads maintained by the Department of Transportation of South Carolina.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Secondary roads are numbered by the county number followed by a unique number for the particular route.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Amtrak Passenger Train operates four passenger routes in South Carolina: Crescent, Palmetto, Silver Meteor and Silver Star.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The Crescent Road serves the cities of Upstate, the silver star serves the cities of Midlands, and the Palmetto and Silver Meteor roads serve the cities of Lower Countries.

sentence: FreightCSX Transportation and Norfolk Southern are the only Class I railway companies in South Carolina, as other freight companies in the state are short lines.

sentence: The Charleston International Airport is the most frequented by passengers.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Just across the North Carolina border, Charlotte/Douglas International Airport, the world's 30th busiest airport, in terms of passengers.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In 2010, South Carolina was one of three states that did not agree to use competitive international language and mathematics standards.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In 2014, the South Carolina Supreme Court ruled that the state had failed to provide "minimumly adequate" education to children in all parts of the state, as required by the state constitution.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina has 1,144 K-12 schools in 85 school districts, of which 712,244 were enrolled in the fall of 2009.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Since the 2008-2009 school year, South Carolina has spent $9,450 per student, placing it 31st in the country for spending per student.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In 2015, the national SAT average was 1490 and the South Carolina average was 1442, 48 points lower than the national average.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina is the only state that has and operates a state-wide school bus system.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In December 2016, the state had a fleet of 5,582 buses, the average vehicle in service being 15 years old (the national average is six) having travelled 236 000 miles.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Half of the state's school buses are over the age of 15 and some would be up to the age of 30.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In 2017, in the proposed budget, the Superintendent of Education Molly Spearman requested the government lease to purchase 1,000 buses to replace the most decrepit vehicles.

name: south_carolina
sentence: An additional 175 buses could be purchased immediately as part of the Crown Treasurer's Master Lease Program.

name: south_carolina
sentence: On January 5, 2017, the United States Environmental Protection Agency granted South Carolina more than $1.1 million to replace 57 school buses with new cleaner models through its Diesel Emissions Reduction Act.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina has a variety of institutions, ranging from large state-funded research universities to small colleges that cultivate liberal arts, religious or military traditions.

name: south_carolina
sentence: For all health care, South Carolina ranks 33rd out of 50 states, according to the Commonwealth Fund, a private health foundation that works to improve the health care system.

name: south_carolina
sentence: According to the Kaiser Family Foundation, the State teenage birth rate was 53 births per 1,000 adolescents, compared to the national average of 41.9 births.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The State infant mortality rate was 9.4 deaths per 1,000 births, compared to the national average of 6.9 deaths.

name: south_carolina
sentence: There were 2.6 physicians per 1,000 compared to the national average of 3.2 physicians.

name: south_carolina
sentence: $5,114 was spent on per capita health expenditures in the government, compared to the national average of $5,283.

name: south_carolina
sentence: There were 26 per cent of children and 13 per cent of seniors living in poverty in the state, compared to 23 per cent and 13 per cent, respectively, doing so in the United States, and 34 per cent of children were overweight or obese, compared to the national average of 32 per cent.
