sentence: Thirty-six (36) separate public universities exist in Texas, 32 of which belong to one of six state university systems.

name: texas
sentence: The discovery of minerals on the lands of the Permanent University Fund, particularly oil, has helped fund the rapid growth of the two largest university systems in the state: the University of Texas system and the Texas A&M system.

name: texas
sentence: The other four academic systems: the University of Houston system, the University of Northern Texas system, the State of Texas system, and the Texas technical system are not funded by the Permanent University Fund.

name: texas
sentence: The Carnegie Foundation ranks four universities in Texas as Tier 1 research institutions: the University of Texas in Austin, the University of A&M in Texas, the University of Houston and the Technical University of Texas.

name: texas
sentence: The University of Texas at Austin and the University of A&M of Texas are the flagship universities of the University of Texas system and the University of A&M of Texas system, respectively.

name: texas
sentence: Both were established by the Texas Constitution and hold interests in the Permanent University Fund.

name: texas
sentence: The state has sought to increase the number of flagship universities by raising some of its seven institutions designated as "emerging research universities".

name: texas
sentence: The two that should first emerge are the University of Houston and the Technical University of Texas, probably in this order according to the discussions on the floor of the 82nd Texas Legislature.

name: texas
sentence: The state is home to a variety of private institutions of higher education, ranging from liberal arts colleges to a nationally recognized first-level research university.

name: texas
sentence: Rice University in Houston is one of the leading universities of teaching and research in the United States and is ranked the 17th best university in the country by US News & World Report.

name: texas
sentence: Trinity University, a private university, mainly undergraduate in liberal arts in San Antonio, ranked first among universities with Bachelors and Masters in the Western United States for 20 consecutive years by US News.

name: texas
sentence: Private universities include Abilene Christian University, Austin College, Baylor University, Mary Hardin–Baylor University and Southwestern University.

name: texas
sentence: Texas universities host three presidential libraries: the George Bush Presidential Library at A&M University in Texas, the Lyndon Baines Johnson Library and Museum at the University of Texas in Austin, and the George W. Bush Presidential Library at the South Methodist University.

name: texas
sentence: Despite the concentration of elite medical centers in the state, the Commonwealth Fund ranks Texas's health care system third among the country's worst.

name: texas
sentence: Texas ranks close to the last in terms of access to health care, quality of care, avoidable hospital expenses and equity among the various groups.

name: texas
sentence: The causes of the state's poor rankings include politics, a high poverty rate and the highest illegal immigration rate in the nation.

name: texas
sentence: In May 2006, Texas launched the "red code" program in response to the report, with the state having 25.1 per cent of the population without health insurance, the largest proportion in the country.

name: texas
sentence: The Trust for America's Health ranked Texas 15th in terms of adult obesity, with 27.2% of the state population obese.

name: texas
sentence: The 2008 survey of obesity among men ranked four cities in Texas among the 25 fattest cities in America; Houston ranked 6th, Dallas 7th, El Paso 8th and Arlington 14th.

name: texas
sentence: Texas had only one city (Austin 21st) in the top 25 among the "most interesting cities" in America.

name: texas
sentence: The same survey positively evaluated the government's obesity initiatives with a "B+".

name: texas
sentence: The State is ranked forty-second in the percentage of residents engaged in the regular exercise according to a 2007 study.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has the highest maternal mortality rate in the developed world, and the death rate of Texas women as a result of pregnancy-related complications doubled between 2010 and 2014, reaching 23.8 per 100,000.

name: texas
sentence: An unmatched rate in any other U.S. state or economically developed country.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has many elite medical research centres.

name: texas
sentence: The State has nine medical schools, three dental schools and two optometry schools.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has two Biosecurity Level 4 (BSL-4) laboratories: one at the University of Texas Medical Branch (UTMB) in Galveston, and the other at the Southwest Foundation for Biomedical Research in San Antonio, BSL-4's first private laboratory in the United States.

name: texas
sentence: The Texas Medical Center in Houston has the world's largest concentration of research and health care institutions, with 47 member institutions.

name: texas
sentence: The Texas Medical Center performs the largest number of cardiac transplants in the world.

name: texas
sentence: The University of Texas Cancer Centre M.D. Anderson in Houston is a well-known academic institution focused on cancer patient care, research, education and prevention.

name: texas
sentence: The facilities at the South Texas Medical Center in San Antonio rank sixth in the impact of clinical medicine research in the United States.

name: texas
sentence: The University of Texas's Centre for Health Sciences is another highly ranked research and educational institution in San Antonio.

name: texas
sentence: The American Heart Association and the University of Texas's Southwest Medical Centre call Dallas home.

name: texas
sentence: The institution's medical school employs the largest number of Nobel Prize laureates in the world.

name: texas
sentence: Texans have always had difficulty crossing Texas because of the large size and rugged terrain of the state.

name: texas
sentence: Texas compensated for the construction of America's largest road and rail networks.

name: texas
sentence: The regulatory authority, the Texas Department of Transportation (TxDOT), maintains the state's vast highway network, and regulates aviation and public transport.

name: texas
sentence: The State is an important transportation centre.

name: texas
sentence: From the Dallas/Fort Worth area, trucks can reach 93 per cent of the country's population in 48 hours, and 37 per cent in 24 hours.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has 33 foreign trade zones (FTZs), the country's largest.

name: texas
sentence: In 2004, a combined total of $298 billion of goods passed through the Texas TFAs.

name: texas
sentence: The first highway in Texas was the Gulf highway opened in 1948 in Houston.

name: texas
sentence: In 2005, 79,535 miles (127,999 km) of public highway crossed Texas (up from 71,000 miles (114,263 km) in 1984).

name: texas
sentence: To finance the recent growth of state highways, Texas has 17 toll roads (see list) with several additional toll routes proposed.

name: texas
sentence: In central Texas, the southern portion of the State Highway 130 toll road has a speed limit of 85 miles per hour (137 km/h), the highest in the country.

name: texas
sentence: All federal and state highways in Texas are paved.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has 730 airports, the second of all the country's states.

name: texas
sentence: Larger in Texas by size and passengers served, the Dallas/Fort Worth International Airport (DFW) is the second largest per region in the United States, and the fourth largest in the world with 18,076 acres (73.15 km2).

name: texas
sentence: In traffic, DFW's airport is the busiest in the state, the fourth busiest in the U.S., and the sixth busiest in the world.

name: texas
sentence: American Airlines Group, the American / American Eagle, the largest airline in the world in the total passenger-miles transported and the size of the passenger fleet, uses DFW as its largest and largest hub.

name: texas
sentence: It ranks as the largest airline in the United States by the number of passengers transported to the country a year and the largest airline in the world by the number of passengers transported.Southwest Airlines, based in Dallas, operates in Dallas Love Field.

name: texas
sentence: Texas's second largest air facility is Houston's George Bush Intercontinental Airport (IAH).

name: texas
sentence: It served as the largest hub for the former Continental Airlines, which was based in Houston; it is the largest hub for United Airlines, the world's third largest airline, per passenger mile.

name: texas
sentence: IAH offers service to the most Mexican destinations of any American airport.

name: texas
sentence: The other five largest airports in the state serve over three million passengers each year: Austin-Bergstrom International Airport, William P. Hobby Airport, San Antonio International Airport, Dallas Love Field and El Paso International Airport.

name: texas
sentence: The smallest airport in the state to be designated as an international airport is the Del Rio International Airport.

name: texas
sentence: Approximately 1,150 seaports point the coast of Texas with over 1,600 km of canals.

name: texas
sentence: Ports employ nearly a million people and process an average of 317 million tonnes.

name: texas
sentence: Texas ports connect to the rest of the U.S. Atlantic coast with the Gulf section of the Intracoastal Waterway.

name: texas
sentence: The port of Houston is now the most frequent port in the United States in foreign tonnage, the second in total tonnage and the tenth in the world in tonnage.

name: texas
sentence: The Houston Canal extends 160 metres wide by 22 metres deep over 80 kilometres long.

name: texas
sentence: Part of the state's cowboy tradition is derived from the large livestock roads that its herders organized in the 19th century to drive cattle to the railways and markets of Kansas, for the expedition to the East.

name: texas
sentence: Cities along the way, such as Baxter Springs, Kansas' first cow town, have developed to take care of seasonal workers and tens of thousands of cattle.

name: texas
sentence: The first railway to operate in Texas was the Buffalo Bayou, Brazos and Colorado Railway, which opened in August 1853.

name: texas
sentence: The first railway to enter Texas from the north, completed in 1872, was the Missouri–Kansas–Texas railway.

name: texas
sentence: With increased access to the railway, the ranchers did not have to take their cattle to the Midwest and shipped beef from Texas.

name: texas
sentence: This has led to a decline in the economy of cows' towns.

name: texas
sentence: Since 1911, Texas has been leading the nation over miles of railway within the state.

name: texas
sentence: The length of the Texas Railway peaked in 1932 at 17,078 miles (27,484 km), but decreased to 14,006 miles (35,540 km) in 2000.

name: texas
sentence: While the Texas Railway Commission initially regulated the state railways, in 2005 the State reallocated these rights to TxDOT.

name: texas
sentence: In the Dallas–Fort Worth area, three public transit agencies provide rail service: Dallas Area Rapid Transit (DART), Denton County Transportation Authority (DCTA) and Trinity Metro.

name: texas
sentence: DART began operating the first light rail system in the southwest of the United States in 1996.

name: texas
sentence: Trinity Railway Express (TRE), which connects Fort Worth and Dallas, is operated by Trinity Metro and DART.

name: texas
sentence: Trinity Metro also operates the TEXRail suburban railway line, linking downtown Fort Worth and Northeast Tarrant County to DFW Airport.

name: texas
sentence: The commuter A train line, operated by DCTA, serves as an extension of the DART Green line in Denton County.

name: texas
sentence: In the Austin area, the Capital Metropolitan Transportation Authority operates a suburban rail service called Capital MetroRail to the northwest suburb.

name: texas
sentence: The Metropolitan Transit Authority of Harris County, Texas (METRO) operates light railway lines in the Houston area.

name: texas
sentence: Amtrak provides Texas with a limited toll rail service.

name: texas
sentence: Three regular routes serve the state: the Texas Eagle daily (Chicago–San Antonio), the triweekly Sunset Limited (New Orleans–Los Angeles), with stops in Texas, and the Heartland Flyer daily (Fort Worth–Oklahoma City).

name: texas
sentence: Texas could have one of the first high-speed lines in the country.

name: texas
sentence: The Texas Central Railway Company has planned the construction of a privately funded high-speed railway line between Dallas and Houston.

name: texas
sentence: The current Constitution of Texas was adopted in 1876.

name: texas
sentence: Like many States, it explicitly provides for the separation of powers.

name: texas
sentence: The State Bill of Rights is much larger than its federal Bill of Rights and contains Texas-specific provisions.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has a plural executive branch that limits the power of the governor, which is a weak executive in comparison to other states.

name: texas
sentence: With the exception of the Secretary of State, electors elect leaders independently, so candidates are directly accountable to the public and not to the Governor.

name: texas
sentence: This electoral system led to the division of certain executive powers between the parties and reduced the governor's ability to carry out a programme.

name: texas
sentence: When Republican President George W. Bush was Governor of Texas, the state had a democratic lieutenant governor, Bob Bullock.

name: texas
sentence: The Executive includes the Governor, the Lieutenant Governor, the Comptroller of Public Accounts, the Land Commissioner, the Attorney General, the Commissioner of Agriculture, the Texas Railway Commission, the State Council of Education and the Secretary of State.

name: texas
sentence: The Texas Bicameral Legislative Assembly consists of the House of Representatives, with 150 members, and one senator, with 31 members.

name: texas
sentence: The Speaker of the House leads the House, and the Lieutenant Governor, the Senator.

name: texas
sentence: The legislature meets in ordinary session every two years for just over a hundred days, but the governor may request extraordinary sessions as often as desired (notably, the legislature cannot meet itself).

name: texas
sentence: The fiscal year of the State shall begin on 1 September.

name: texas
sentence: Texas's judicial power is one of the most complex in the United States, with many layers and overlapping jurisdictions.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has two courts of last resort: the Texas Supreme Court, for civil matters, and the Texas Criminal Court of Appeal.

name: texas
sentence: With the exception of certain municipal benches, partisan elections select judges at all levels of the judiciary; the governor fills vacancies by appointment.

name: texas
sentence: Texas is remarkable for its use of capital punishment, having led the country to executions since the death penalty was restored in Gregg v. Georgia (see capital punishment in Texas).

name: texas
sentence: The Texas Ranger Division of the Texas Department of Public Safety is a law enforcement agency within the jurisdiction of the State.

name: texas
sentence: Over the years, Texas Rangers have investigated crimes ranging from murder to political corruption.

name: texas
sentence: They acted as riot police and inspectors, protected the governor of Texas, tracked fugitives and acted as a paramilitary force both for the republic and for the state.

name: texas
sentence: The Texas Rangers were created informally by Stephen F. Austin in 1823 and were formally constituted in 1835.

name: texas
sentence: The Rangers were an integral part of several important events in the history of Texas and some of the most well-known criminal cases in Old West history.

name: texas
sentence: The Texas Constitution defines the responsibilities of county governments, which serve as agents of the state.

name: texas
sentence: The so-called Commissioners Courts and Judges Courts are elected as the administrative body.

name: texas
sentence: Most of the state's cities, with more than 5,000 inhabitants, have autonomous governments.

name: texas
sentence: The vast majority of them have charters for forms of council-managerial government, by which voters elect members of the council, who hire a director of a professional town as an operating officer.

name: texas
sentence: In the 1870s, white democrats regained power in the state legislature of the biracial coalition at the end of the reconstruction.

name: texas
sentence: At the beginning of the twentieth century, Parliament passed bills to impose voting taxes, followed by white primaries; these measures effectively deprived most blacks, poor whites and Mexican Americans.

name: texas
sentence: In the 1890s, 100,000 blacks voted in the state; in 1906, only 5,000 could vote.

name: texas
sentence: As a result, the Democratic Party dominated Texas's politics at the beginning of the century, imposing racial segregation and white supremacy.

name: texas
sentence: It held power until the adoption, in the mid-1960s, of national legislation on civil rights, which enforces the constitutional rights of all citizens.

name: texas
sentence: Although Texas was essentially a single-party state during this period and democratic primary was considered "the real election," the Democratic Party had conservative and liberal factions, which became more pronounced after the New Deal.

name: texas
sentence: In addition, several party factions separated briefly in the 1930s and 1940s.

name: texas
sentence: The conservative white voters of the state began supporting candidates for the Republican presidency in the mid-20th century.

name: texas
sentence: After this period, they also supported the Republicans for local and state offices, and most whites became members of the Republican Party.

name: texas
sentence: The party has also attracted some minorities, but many have continued to vote for democratic candidates.

name: texas
sentence: The passage to the Republican Party is largely attributed to the fact that the Democratic Party became increasingly liberal during the 20th century, and therefore increasingly uncontrollable with the average voter in Texas.

name: texas
sentence: Since Texas has always been a conservative state, voters have turned to the GOP, which now more closely reflects their beliefs.

name: texas
sentence: The commentators also attributed this change to Republican political consultant Karl Rove, who managed many political campaigns in Texas in the 1980s and 1990s.

name: texas
sentence: Other reasons cited included court-ordered redistribution and demographic change in relation to the Sun Belt that favoured the Republican Party and conservatism.

name: texas
sentence: The 2003 Texas redistribution of Congressional districts led by Republican Tom DeLay was called by the New York Times "an extreme case of partisan Gerrymandering".

name: texas
sentence: A group of democratic legislators, the "Texas Eleven", fled the state in an attempt to abuse quorum to prevent the legislator from acting, but failed.

name: texas
sentence: The state had already redesigned as a result of the 2000 census.

name: texas
sentence: Despite these efforts, the legislator has adopted a map strongly in favour of Republicans, based on 2000 data and ignoring the estimates of nearly one million new residents in the state since then.

name: texas
sentence: Career lawyers and analysts in the Department of Justice objected to the plan as diluting the votes of African-American and Hispanic voters, but the political appointees stole and approved it.

name: texas
sentence: In League of United Latin American Citizens v. Perry (2006), the National Supreme Court ruled in favour of the state (and Republicans).

name: texas
sentence: In the 2014 Texas election, the Tea Party movement made great strides, with many of the Tea Party's favourites elected to power, including Dan Patrick as Lieutenant Governor, Ken Paxton as Attorney General, as well as many other candidates, including Conservative Republican Greg Abbott as Governor.

name: texas
sentence: The voters of Texas are leaning towards fiscal conservatism, while taking advantage of the huge federal investment in the state in military and other facilities obtained by the power of the South Solid in the 20th century.

name: texas
sentence: They also tend to have social conservative values.

name: texas
sentence: Since 1980, most voters in Texas have supported Republican presidential candidates.

name: texas
sentence: In 2000 and 2004, Republican George W. Bush won Texas with 59.3 per cent and 60.1 per cent respectively, partly because of his status as "preferential son" as former state governor.

name: texas
sentence: John McCain won the state in 2008, but with less than Bush's margin of victory than 55 percent of the vote.

name: texas
sentence: Austin, Dallas, Houston and San Antonio are constantly focusing on democracy in local and state elections.

name: texas
sentence: The demographic evolution of the state can lead to a change in its overall political alignment, as a majority population of Black and Hispanic/Latino voters supports the Democratic Party.

name: texas
sentence: Residents of counties along the Rio Grande closer to the Mexico-United States border, where there are many Latin American residents, generally vote for Democratic Party candidates, while most other rural and suburban areas of Texas voted for Republican Party candidates.

name: texas
sentence: Starting with the 2014 general election, a large majority of the U.S. Texas House delegation are Republicans, as well as the two United States.

name: texas
sentence: - Senators. - Senators.

name: texas
sentence: At the 114th Congress of the United States, of the 36 congressional districts in Texas, 24 were held by Republicans and 11 by Democrats.

name: texas
sentence: A seat is vacant.

name: texas
sentence: Texas senators are John Cornyn and Ted Cruz.

name: texas
sentence: Since 1994, the Texans have not elected a democrat to a state-wide post.

name: texas
sentence: Democratic voters in the state are mainly Liberal and minority groups in Austin, Beaumont, Dallas, El Paso, Houston and San Antonio, as well as minority voters in eastern and southern Texas.

name: texas
sentence: Texas banned sanctuaries, but the mayor of Houston Sylvester Turner promised the city wouldn't help ICE agents.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has a reputation of very severe criminal punishment for criminal offences.

name: texas
sentence: It is one of the 32 states that use capital punishment, and since the Supreme Court of the United States allowed the resumption of capital punishment in 1976, 40 per cent of all United States executions have taken place in Texas.

name: texas
sentence: In 2008, Texas had the fourth highest rate of incarceration in the United States.It also has strong self-defence laws, allowing citizens to use lethal force to defend themselves, their families or their property.

name: texas
sentence: While American football has long been regarded as "king" in the state, Texans enjoy a wide variety of sports.

name: texas
sentence: Texans can promote a plethora of professional sports teams.

name: texas
sentence: Within the four major professional leagues, Texas has two NFL teams (the Dallas Cowboys and the Houston Texans), two major League baseball teams (the Houston Astros and the Texas Rangers), three NBA teams (the San Antonio Spurs, the Houston Rockets and the Dallas Mavericks) and one National Hockey League team (the Dallas Stars).

name: texas
sentence: The Dallas–Fort Worth Metroplex is one of the twelve U.S. metropolitan areas that host sports teams from all professional "Big Four" leagues.

name: texas
sentence: Apart from the Big Four, Texas also has a WNBA team (the Dallas Wings) and two teams from Major League Soccer (the Houston Dynamo and FC Dallas).

name: texas
sentence: College athletics has a profound meaning in Texas culture, especially football.

name: texas
sentence: The State has twelve schools in the I-FBS Division, the most populous of the nation.

name: texas
sentence: Four of the state universities, the Baylor Bears, Texas Longhorns, TCU Horned Frogs and Texas Tech Red Raiders, participate in the Great 12 Conference.

name: texas
sentence: Texas A&M Aggies left the Big 12 and joined the South-East Conference in 2012, which led the Big 12 to invite the TCU to join; TCU was previously at the Mountain West Conference.

name: texas
sentence: The Houston Cougars and SMU Mustangs participate in the American athletic conference.

name: texas
sentence: The Bobcats of the State of Texas and the UT's Arlington Mavericks participate in the Sun Belt conference.

name: texas
sentence: Four of the state's schools claim at least one national football championship: Texas Longhorns, Texas A&M Aggies, TCU Horned Frogs, and SMU Mustangs.

name: texas
sentence: According to an I-A Division investigation, there is a rivalry between the University of Oklahoma and the University of Texas at Austin, Red River Shootout, which ranks third in the nation.

name: texas
sentence: TCU's horned frogs and the SMU Mustangs also share a rivalry and participate each year in the battle for the Iron Skullet.

name: texas
sentence: A fierce rivalry, the Lone Star Showdown, also exists between the two largest universities in the state, Texas A&M University and the University of Texas in Austin.

name: texas
sentence: The athletic side of the Lone Star Showdown rivalry was suspended after the Texas Aggies joined the Southeast Conference.

name: texas
sentence: The University Interscholastic League (UIL) organizes most competitions in primary and secondary schools.

name: texas
sentence: The events organised by UIL include athletics competitions (the most popular being secondary football) as well as artistic and academic disciplines.

name: texas
sentence: Texans also love rodeo.

name: texas
sentence: The world's first rodeo was hosted in Pecos, Texas.

name: texas
sentence: The annual Houston Livestock Show and Rodeo is the world's largest rodeo.

name: texas
sentence: It starts with hikes from several points of the state that meet in Reliant Park.

name: texas
sentence: The Southwest Exhibition and Livestock Fair in Fort Worth is the oldest rodeo in state history.

name: texas
sentence: Dallas hosts the Texas State Fair each year in Fair Park.

name: texas
sentence: Texas Motor Speedway has hosted annual NASCAR Cup Series and IndyCar Series racing since 1997.

name: texas
sentence: Since 2012, Austin's Circuit of the Americas has hosted a Formula 1 World Championship tour – the first of a permanent road circuit in the United States since the 1980 Grand Prix at Watkins Glen International – as well as Grand Prix motorcycle races, FIA World Endurance Championship and United SportsCar Championship.

name: utah
sentence: Utah (YOO-tah, (listening) YOO-taw) is a state in the western United States of America.

name: utah
sentence: It is bordered by Colorado to the east, Wyoming to the northeast, Idaho to the north, Arizona to the south, and Nevada to the west.

name: utah
sentence: It also touches a corner of New Mexico in the south-east.

name: utah
sentence: Of the fifty American states, Utah is the 13th largest by region; with a population of more than three million, it is the 30th most populous and the 11th least dense.

name: utah
sentence: Urban development is concentrated mainly in two regions: the Wasatch Front in the north-central part of the state, which is home to about two thirds of the population and includes the capital, Salt Lake City; and Washington County in the south, with over 170,000 inhabitants.

name: utah
sentence: Most of the western Utah is in the Great Basin.

name: utah
sentence: The territory of modern Utah has been inhabited by various Aboriginal groups for thousands of years, including the former Puebloans, Navajo and Ute.

name: utah
sentence: The Spaniards were the first Europeans to arrive in the middle of the 16th century, although the region's difficult geography and climate made it a peripheral part of New Spain and later Mexico.

name: utah
sentence: Even though it was part of Mexico, many early Utah settlers were American, especially Mormons fleeing the marginalization and persecution of the United States.

name: utah
sentence: After the war between Mexico and America, it is part of Utah territory, which includes what is now Colorado and Nevada.

name: utah
sentence: Disputes between the dominant Mormon community and the federal government delayed Utah's admission as a state; it was only after the prohibition of polygamy that it was admitted as 45th in 1896.

name: utah
sentence: Just over half of all Uthahs are Mormons, the vast majority of whom are members of the Church of Jesus Christ of Last-Day Saints (LDS Church), which has its world headquarters in Salt Lake City.

name: utah
sentence: Utah is the only state in which the majority of the population belongs to a single church.

name: utah
sentence: The LDS Church greatly influences Utahn's culture, politics and daily life, although, since the 1990s, the state has become more religiously and secularly diverse.

name: utah
sentence: The State has a very diverse economy, with important sectors such as transportation, education, information technology and research, government services, mining, and an important tourist destination for outdoor recreation.

name: utah
sentence: In 2013, the U.S. Census Bureau estimated Utah to have the fastest population in any state.

name: utah
sentence: St. George was the fastest growing metropolitan area in the United States from 2000 to 2005.

name: utah
sentence: Utah also has the highest average income and lowest income inequality of all U.S. states.

name: utah
sentence: A 2012 Gallup National Survey revealed that Utah was generally the "best future life" based on 13 forward-looking measures, including various measures of economic prospects, lifestyle and health.

name: utah
sentence: It is said that the name Utah derives from the name of the tribe Ute, that is, "people of the mountains."

name: utah
sentence: However, no such word really exists in the language of the Utes, and the Utes refer to themselves as Noochee.

name: utah
sentence: The meaning of Utes as "the mountain people" has been attributed to the neighboring Pueblo Indians, as well as to the word Apache Yuttahih, which means "the one who is higher" or "the ones who are higher".

name: utah
sentence: In Spanish, Yuta was pronounced.

name: utah
sentence: Thousands of years before the arrival of European explorers, the Puebloans Ancestral and the Fremont people lived in what is now called Utah, some of which spoke the languages of the Uto-Aztecan group.

name: utah
sentence: The people of ancient Pueblo built their houses by excavations in the mountains, and the people of Fremont built straw houses before disappearing from the area around the 15th century.

name: utah
sentence: Another group of Amerindians, Navajo, settled in the region around the 18th century.

name: utah
sentence: In the middle of the 18th century, other Uto-Aztecan tribes, including the Goshute, the Paiute, the Shoshone and the Ute people, also settled in the area.

name: utah
sentence: These five groups were present at the arrival of the first European explorers.

name: utah
sentence: The southern region of Utah was explored by the Spaniards in 1540, led by Francisco Vázquez de Coronado, while seeking the legendary Cíbola.

name: utah
sentence: A group led by two Catholic priests – sometimes called the Domínguez-Escalante expedition – left Santa Fe in 1776, hoping to find a route to the Californian coast.

name: utah
sentence: The expedition went north to Lake Utah and met with Aboriginal residents.

name: utah
sentence: The Spaniards made further explorations in the area but were not interested in colonizing the region because of its desert nature.

name: utah
sentence: In 1821, when Mexico gained its independence from Spain, the region became known as part of its Alta California territory.

name: utah
sentence: In the early nineteenth century, European trappers and fur traders explored parts of Utah from Canada and the United States.

name: utah
sentence: The town of Provo, Utah, was named in honour of Étienne Provost, who visited the region in 1825.

name: utah
sentence: The city of Ogden, Utah, is named after Peter Skene Ogden, a Canadian explorer who sells furs in the Weber Valley.

name: utah
sentence: At the end of 1824 Jim Bridger became the first known English speaker to visit Great Salt Lake.

name: utah
sentence: Because of the high salinity of his waters, He thought he had found the Pacific Ocean; he later learned that this body of water was a giant salt lake.

name: utah
sentence: Following the discovery of the lake, hundreds of American and Canadian traders and trappers established trading posts in the area.

name: utah
sentence: In the 1830s, thousands of migrants travelling from the eastern United States to the western United States began making stops in the area of Great Salt Lake, then known as Lake Youta.

name: utah
sentence: After the death of Joseph Smith in 1844, Brigham Young, as president of the Quorum of Twelve, became the effective leader of the LDS Church in Nauvoo, Illinois.

name: utah
sentence: To settle the growing conflicts between his people and his neighbours, Young agreed with Illinois Governor Thomas Ford in October 1845 that the Mormons would leave by the following year.

name: utah
sentence: Young and the first group of Mormon pioneers reached the Salt Lake valley on July 24, 1847.

name: utah
sentence: Over the next 22 years, more than 70,000 pioneers have crossed the plains and settled in Utah.

name: utah
sentence: During the early years, Brigham Young and the thousands of first settlers in Salt Lake City struggled to survive.

name: utah

name: utah

sentence: Beginning in the early 20th century, with the establishment of national parks such as Bryce Canyon National Park and Zion National Park, Utah became known for its natural beauty.

sentence: The dry and powdery snow of the Wasatch chain is considered to be one of the best skiers in the world (the state license plate once claimed "the greatest snow on earth").

sentence: Salt Lake City won the 2002 Olympic Winter Games, which greatly boosted the economy.

sentence: In 1957 Utah established the Utah State Parks Commission with four parks.

name: utah
sentence: Today, Utah State Parks manage 43 parks and several undeveloped areas totalling more than 95,000 acres (380 km2) of land and more than one million acres (4,000 km2) of water.

sentence: Transport management and urbanization are important policy issues, as development consumes agricultural land and wild areas, and transport is a major cause of poor air quality in Utah.

name: utah
sentence: Utah is known for its natural diversity and has features ranging from dry deserts with sand dunes to prosperous pine forests in mountain valleys.

name: utah
sentence: It is a rugged and geographically diverse state with the convergence of three distinct geological regions: the Rocky Mountains, the Great Basin and the Colorado Plateau.

name: utah
sentence: Utah covers an area of 84,899 m2 (119,890 km2).

name: utah
sentence: It is bordered by Idaho in the north, Wyoming in the north and east; Colorado in the east; New Mexico in the south-east; Arizona in the south; and Nevada in the west.

name: utah
sentence: Only three U.S. states (Utah, Colorado and Wyoming) have exclusively latitude and longitude lines as their boundaries.

name: utah
sentence: One of the defining features of Utah is its variety of terrain.

name: utah
sentence: In the middle of the third north of the state is the Wasatch chain, which reaches heights of almost 12,000 ft (3,700 m) above sea level.

name: utah
sentence: Utah is home to world-renowned ski resorts made popular by light, soft snow and winter storms that regularly pour up to three feet of it during the night.

name: utah
sentence: In the north-eastern part of the state, from the east to the west, are the Uinta Mountains, which reach heights of more than 13,000 feet (4,000 m).

sentence: The highest point of the state, Kings Peak, at 13,528 feet (4,123 m), is in the Uinta Mountains.

name: utah
sentence: It extends approximately from the city of Brigham at the north end to Nephi at the south end.

name: utah
sentence: Approximately 75 per cent of the population of the state lives in this corridor, and population growth is rapid.

sentence: Western Utah is primarily an arid desert with a basin and a range topography.

name: utah
sentence: Small mountain ranges and rough terrain punctuate the landscape.

name: utah
sentence: The Bonneville Salt Flats are an exception, being relatively flat because of once forming the bed of former Lake Bonneville.

name: utah
sentence: Great Salt Lake, Lake Utah, Lake Sevier and Lake Rush are all remnants of this old freshwater lake that once covered most of the eastern Great Basin.

name: utah
sentence: To the west of the Great Salt Lake, which extends to the Nevada border, is the arid desert of the Great Salt Lake.

name: utah
sentence: An exception to this aridity is the Snake Valley, which is (relatively) lush due to the large springs and wetlands fed by groundwater from snowmelt in the Snake Range, the Deep Creek Range and other high mountains west of the Snake Valley.

name: utah
sentence: Great Basin National Park is located just above the Nevada State Line in the south of the Snake Range.

name: utah
sentence: One of the most impressive but least visited attractions in western Utah is Notch Peak, the highest limestone cliff in North America, west of Delta.

name: utah
sentence: Much of the picturesque landscape of the south and south-east (especially the Colorado Plateau area) is sandstone, particularly Kayenta sandstone and Navajo sandstone.

name: utah
sentence: The Colorado River and its tributaries flow through sandstone, creating some of the most striking and wildest terrains in the world (the area around the confluence of the Colorado and Green rivers was the last to be mapped in the lower 48 United States).

name: utah
sentence: Wind and rain also carved soft sandstone for millions of years.

name: utah
sentence: Canyons, gulls, arches, pinnacles, buttocks, bluffs and mesas are common in south-central and southeastern Utah.

name: utah
sentence: This land is a central feature of state and federal protected national parks such as Arches, Bryce Canyon, Canyonlands, Capitol Reef and Zion, Cedar Breaks, Grand Staircase-Escalante, Hovenweep and Natural Bridges National Monuments, Glen Canyon National Recreation Area (popular tourist destination site, Powell Lake), Dead Horse Point and Goblin Valley State Parks, and Monument Valley.

name: utah
sentence: Like most western and southwestern states, the federal government owns much of the land in Utah.

name: utah
sentence: Utah is the only state where every county contains a national forest.

name: utah
sentence: Utah has a dry, semi-arid climate in the desert, although its numerous mountains have a wide variety of climates, the highest points in the mountains of Uinta being above the wood line.

name: utah
sentence: Dry weather is the result of the state location in the rain shadow of Sierra Nevada, California.

name: utah
sentence: Half of the eastern state is in the rain shadow of the Wasatch Mountains.

name: utah
sentence: The main source of precipitation for the state is the Pacific Ocean, with the state usually on the road to major Pacific storms from October to May.

name: utah
sentence: In summer, the state, particularly the south and east of Utah, is on the path to monsoon moisture from the Gulf of California.

name: utah
sentence: Most lowlands receive less than 12 inches (305 mm) of precipitation per year, although corridor I-15, including the densely populated Wasatch Front, receives approximately 15 inches (381 mm).

name: utah
sentence: The Great Salt Lake Desert is the driest area of the state, with less than 5 inches (127 mm).

name: utah
sentence: Snowfalls are common in all valleys, with the exception of southern valleys.

name: utah
sentence: Although St. George receives only about 3 inches (76 mm) per year, Salt Lake City sees about 60 inches (1,524 mm), increased by effect snow Lake of Great Salt Lake, increasing total snowfall to the south, southeast and east of the lake.

name: utah
sentence: Some areas of the Wasatch range on the lake effect trail receive up to 500 inches (12,700 mm) per year.

name: utah
sentence: This micro-climate of increased snowfall from Great Salt Lake extends over the whole vicinity of the lake.

name: utah
sentence: The cotton canyons adjacent to Salt Lake City are located in the right position to receive more precipitation from the lake.

name: utah
sentence: The ever-deep snowfowl led the Utah ski industry to adopt the slogan "The greatest snow on earth" in the 1980s.

name: utah
sentence: In winter, temperature inversions are a common phenomenon in Utah basins and valleys, resulting in thick fog and fog that can last for weeks at a time, especially in the Uintah basin.

name: utah
sentence: Although at other times of the year its air quality is good, winter reversals give Salt Lake City one of the worst winter pollution in the country.

name: utah
sentence: Previous studies have shown a widespread decline in snow quantity above Utah, accompanied by a decline in the snow-precipitation ratio, while anecdotal claims have been made that the measured changes in Utah snow quantity are misleading and do not reflect actual changes.

name: utah
sentence: A 2012 study found that the proportion of winter precipitation (January to March) that falls as snow has decreased by 9% over the last half century, a combined result of a significant increase in precipitation and a slight decrease in snowfall.

name: utah
sentence: Meanwhile, the depth of snow observed in Utah decreased and was accompanied by a steady decrease in snow cover and surface albedo.

name: utah
sentence: Weather systems likely to produce precipitation in Utah have decreased in number, with those producing snowfall decreasing at a much higher rate.

name: utah
sentence: Utah's temperatures are extreme, with cold temperatures in winter due to its elevation, and very hot summers on a state scale (except for mountain areas and high mountain valleys).

name: utah
sentence: Utah is usually protected from large explosions of cold air by mountains to the north and east of the state, although large arctic explosions may sometimes reach the state.

name: utah
sentence: Average January temperatures vary from about 30°F (−1°C) in some northern valleys to nearly 55°F (13°C) in St. George.

name: utah
sentence: Temperatures below 0°F (−18°C) should be expected occasionally in most parts of the state in most years, although some regions often see it (for example, the city of Randolph has an average of about fifty days a year with such low temperatures).

name: utah
sentence: In July, average heights range from about 85 to 100 °F (29 to 38 °C).

name: utah
sentence: However, low humidity and high altitude usually result in large temperature variations, resulting in cool nights on most summer days.

name: utah
sentence: The record temperature in Utah was 118°F (48°C), recorded south of St. George on July 4, 2007, and the low record was -69°F (−56°C), recorded at Peter Sinks in the Bear River Mountains in northern Utah on February 1, 1985.

name: utah
sentence: However, the record level for a inhabited site was -49°F (−45°C) at Woodruff on 12 December 1932.

name: utah
sentence: Utah, like most Western United States, has a few days of thunderstorms.

name: utah
sentence: On average, there are less than 40 days of stormy activity in the year, although these storms may be briefly intense when they occur.

name: utah
sentence: They are more likely to occur during the monsoon season, from mid-July to mid-September, especially in southern and eastern Utah.

name: utah
sentence: Dry lightning strikes and the general dry weather often triggers forest fires in the summer, while intense thunderstorms can cause flash floods, especially in the rugged southern Utah terrain.

name: utah
sentence: Although spring is the wettest season in northern Utah, late summer is the wettest time for much of the south and east of the state.

name: utah
sentence: The tornadoes are uncommon in Utah, with an average of two hitting the state each year, rarely more intense than the EF1.

name: utah
sentence: One exception, however, was the unprecedented F2 Salt Lake City Tornado, which moved directly to downtown Salt Lake City on August 11, 1999, killing one person, wounding another sixty, and causing approximately $170 million in damage.

name: utah
sentence: The only other deadly tornado reported in Utah's history was a 7-year-old girl who was killed while camping in Summit County on July 6, 1884.

name: utah
sentence: The last tornado of intensity above (E)F0 occurred on September 8, 2002, when an F2 tornado hit Manti.

name: utah
sentence: On 11 August 1993, an F3 tornado struck the Uinta Mountains north of Duchesne at an altitude of 10,500 feet (3,200 m), causing damage to a Boy Scout camp.

name: utah
sentence: It's the strongest tornado ever recorded in Utah.

sentence: Utah is home to more than 600 vertebrate animals, as well as numerous invertebrates and insects.

name: virginia
sentence: Virginia is predominantly Christian and Protestant; Baptist denominations combined to form the largest group with about 26 percent of the population in 2014, and a total of about 763,655 members in 2010.

sentence: Roman Catholics are the second largest religious group with 673,853 members.

name: virginia
sentence: The Synod of Virginia is responsible for the congregations of the Lutheran Church.

name: virginia
sentence: Presbyterian, Pentecostal, Congregational and Episcopal members each accounted for less than two per cent of the population in 2010.

sentence: The episcopal diocese of Virginia, South Virginia, and South West Virginia support the various episcopal churches.

sentence: Although Virginia's law allowed parishioners to determine the affiliation of their church, the diocese claimed the buildings and properties of the secessionist churches.

sentence: While the Jewish population of the State is small, the Jewish sites organized date back to 1789 with the Congregation Beth Ahaba.

sentence: Virginia's economy has a variety of sources of income, including local and federal government, the military, agriculture and high technology.

name: virginia
sentence: The average government wage per job was 63,281, the 11th highest nationally, and the gross domestic product (GDP) was $476.4 billion in 2018, the 13th largest among the U.S. states.

name: virginia
sentence: Prior to the March 2020 Coronavirus recession, Virginia had 4.36 million people employed with an unemployment rate of 2.9 per cent, but jobless claims from the virus increased by more than 10 per cent in early April 2020, before returning to 4.9 per cent in November, the 13th lowest in the country.

name: virginia
sentence: However, Virginia ranks first in terms of the timely review of unemployment benefits due to the pandemic.

name: virginia
sentence: Although the Gini Index shows that Virginia has less income inequality than the national average, the middle class of the state is also smaller than the majority of states.

sentence: Virginia has the highest defence spending in any state per capita, providing approximately 900,000 jobs to the Commonwealth.

sentence: Many Virginians work for federal agencies in Northern Virginia, including the Central Intelligence Agency and the Department of Defence, as well as the National Science Foundation, the United States Geological Survey, and the United States Patent and Trademark Office.

sentence: In its state government, Virginia employs 106,143 public employees, who have median income of $44,656 in 2013.

sentence: Virginia's business community has been highly classified by a variety of publications.

sentence: Virginia has the largest concentration of technology workers in any state, and the fourth largest number of technology workers after California, Texas and New York.

sentence: North Virginia, formerly considered the state's dairy capital, is now home to software, communication technologies, defence companies, particularly in the Dulles technology corridor and the Tysons Corner regions.

name: virginia
sentence: Tourism in Virginia supported approximately 234,000 jobs in 2018, making tourism the fifth largest industry in the state.

sentence: Virginia also saw 1.1 million international tourists in 2018, a 5% increase over 2017.

name: virginia
sentence: In 2017, agriculture occupied 28% of Virginia's land with 7.8 million acres (12,188 m2; 31,565 km2) of agricultural land.

name: virginia
sentence: Nearly 54,000 Virginians work on 43,225 state farms, an average of 181 acres (0.28 m2; 0.73 km2).

name: virginia
sentence: Although agriculture has declined significantly since 1960, when there were twice as many farms, it remains Virginia's largest industry, accounting for more than 334,000 jobs.

sentence: Soybean was Virginia's most profitable crop in 2017, before maize and cut flowers were the other major agricultural products.

sentence: Commercial fisheries support 18,220 jobs from 2020, while recreational fisheries support 5,893 other jobs.

sentence: Virginia collects personal income tax from those with income above a reporting threshold; there are five income brackets, ranging from 2.0% to 5.75 per cent of taxable income.

name: virginia
sentence: The government's sales and use tax rate is 4.3%.

sentence: There is an additional local tax of 1%, for a total of 5.3% combined sales tax on most Virginia purchases.

sentence: The sales tax rate is higher in three regions: Northern Virginia (6%), Hampton Roads (6%) and the Historical Triangle (7%).

name: virginia
sentence: Unlike most states, Virginia collects sales tax on grocery, but at a lower rate than the general sales tax; the sales tax on food and certain essential personal health products is 2.5%.

name: virginia
sentence: Virginia's property tax is set and collected at the local government level and varies across the Commonwealth.

name: virginia
sentence: Real property is also taxed locally based on 100 per cent of the fair market value.

sentence: Starting in fiscal 2018, the median property tax rate per $100 of the assessed taxable value was $1.07 for cities, $0.67 for counties and $0.17 for cities; city rates are lower because cities (unlike cities) have a narrow range of responsibilities and are subordinate to counties.

name: virginia
sentence: Of the tax revenues of local governments, approximately 61 per cent come from property taxes, approximately 24 per cent from taxes on tangible personal property, sales and use, and operating licences, and 15 per cent from other taxes (such as restaurant meal taxes, public service corporation property taxes, utility taxes and hotel taxes).

sentence: Virginia's culture has been popularized and disseminated throughout America and the South by such personalities as George Washington, Thomas Jefferson and Robert E. Lee.

sentence: Virginia has a mixed health record, and has been ranked as the 15th most healthy general condition according to the health rankings of the United Health Foundation 2019.

sentence: Virginia was 19th lowest among the United States in its number of premature deaths, with 6,914 deaths per 100,000, and 24th with an infant mortality rate of 5.9 per 1,000 live births.

sentence: As a result of the Byrd Road Act of 1932, the state government controlled most of Virginia's roads, instead of a local county administration as usual in other states.

name: virginia
sentence: In 2018, the Virginia Department of Transportation owns and operates 57,867 miles (93,128 km) of the 70,105 miles (112,823 km) of state roads, making it the third largest state road network in the United States.

sentence: In 1619, the first General Assembly of Virginia met at Jamestown Church and had 22 local elected officials, making Virginia's legislature the oldest in North America.

name: virginia
sentence: These representatives became an official house of Burgesses in 1642 and governed by the Governor's Council appointed by the Crown until Virginia declared independence in 1776.

name: virginia
sentence: The government now operates under Virginia's seventh Constitution, which was approved by voters in 1971 and is similar to the federal structure in that it provides for three branches: a strong legislature, an executive power and a unified judicial system.

name: virginia
sentence: Virginia's Legislative Assembly is bicameral with a 100-member House of Delegates and a 40-member Senator, who together draft laws for the Commonwealth.

name: virginia
sentence: Delegates are appointed for two-year terms, while senators are appointed for four-year terms, with the most recent elections taking place in November 2019.

name: virginia

name: virginia

name: virginia

name: virginia
sentence: The legislature meets annually from the second Wednesday of the year, usually for 60 days in even years and 48 days in odd years because of the state's half-yearly budget, although special sessions may be convened either by the governor or with the agreement of two-thirds of the two chambers.

sentence: Special sessions were convened in 2019 on firearms control and in 2020 on police reform and the impact of coronavirus on the State budget.

name: virginia
sentence: The judges and judges who make up the Virginia judicial system, also the oldest in America, are elected by majority in the House and Senate without the Governor's advice, in a way the Virginia legislature is stronger than its executive.

name: washington
sentence: Washington, officially Washington State, is a state in the Northwestern Pacific region of the United States.

name: washington
sentence: Named for George Washington, the first American president, the state was formed from the western part of the Washington territory, which was ceded by the British Empire in 1846, in accordance with the Oregon Treaty in the settlement of the Oregon border dispute.

name: washington
sentence: The state, bordered to the west by the Pacific Ocean, Oregon to the south, Idaho to the east and the Canadian province of British Columbia to the north, was admitted to the Union as the 42nd state in 1889.

name: washington
sentence: Olympia is the capital of the State

name: washington
sentence: Washington is often referred to as Washington State to distinguish it from the nation's capital, Washington, D.C.

name: washington
sentence: Washington is the 18th largest state, with an area of 71,362 square miles (184,827 km2), and the 13th most populated state, with more than 7,6 million people.

name: washington
sentence: About 60 per cent of Washington's people live in the Seattle metropolitan area, the centre of transportation, business and industry along Puget Sound, a Pacific Ocean entrance consisting of many islands, deep fjords and glacier-drilled bays.

name: washington
sentence: The rest of the state consists of deep temperate rainforests to the west; mountain ranges to the west, the centre, the north-east and the extreme south-east; and a semi-arid basin region to the east, the centre and the south, ceded to intensive agriculture.

name: washington
sentence: Washington is the second most populated state on the west and west coasts of the United States, after California.

name: washington
sentence: Mount Rainier, an active stratovolcan, is the highest altitude in the state, at nearly 14,411 feet (4,392 metres), and is the most topographically prominent mountain in the adjacent United States.

name: washington
sentence: Washington is a major producer of lumber; its rugged surface is rich in Douglas-fir stands, hemlock, ponderosa pine, white pine, spruce, larch and cedar.

name: washington
sentence: Washington is the largest national producer of apples, hops, pears, red raspberries, mint oil and sweet cherries, and ranks first in the production of apricots, asparagus, dried peas, grapes, lentils, peppermint oil and potatoes.

name: washington
sentence: Livestock and livestock products make a significant contribution to overall agricultural revenues, and commercial salmon, halibut and groundfish fisheries make a significant contribution to the government economy.

name: washington
sentence: Washington is the second largest wine producer in California.

name: washington
sentence: Manufacturing industries in Washington include aircraft and missiles, shipbuilding and other transportation equipment, food processing, metals and metal products, chemicals and machinery.

name: washington
sentence: Washington has over 1,000 dams, including the Grand Coulee Dam, built for various purposes, including irrigation, electricity, flood control and water storage.

name: washington
sentence: Washington is one of the richest and most socially liberal states of the country.

name: washington
sentence: The State is consistently among the best in terms of life expectancy and low unemployment.

sentence: Together with Colorado, Washington was one of the first to legalize medicinal and recreational cannabis, was one of the first 36 states to legalize same-sex marriage, doing so in 2012, and was one of the only four states in the United States to provide legal abortions on request prior to the 1973 Supreme Court decision in Roe v. Canada.

sentence: Similarly, Washington voters approved a 2008 referendum on the legalization of physician-assisted suicide and are currently one of the nine states, as well as the District of Columbia, for legalizing this practice.

Stanton found the name too similar to the District of Columbia (the National Capital, itself containing the City of Washington), and proposed to appoint the new territory after President Washington.

name: washington
sentence: Washington is the only American state named after a president.

sentence: Confusion over the state of Washington and the city of Washington, D.C. led to renaming proposals during the state process for Washington in 1889, including David Dudley Field II's suggestion to name the new state "Tacoma".

sentence: The residents of Washington (known as "Washingtonians") and the Pacific Northwest simply refer to the state as "Washington", and the nation's capital "Washington, D.C.", "the other Washington", or simply "D.C."

sentence: Washington is the most northwestern state of the contiguous United States.

name: washington
sentence: It borders the Idaho to the east, bounded primarily by the meridian running north of the confluence of the Snake River and the Clearwater River (approximately 117°02'23" to the west), with the exception of the southernmost section where the boundary follows the Snake River.

name: washington
sentence: Oregon is to the south, with the Columbia River forming the western part and the 46th parallel forming the eastern part of the Oregon-Washington boundary.

sentence: Washington is part of an area known as Pacific Northwest, a term that always refers at least to Washington and Oregon, and that may or may not include some or all of the following, as intended by the user: Idaho, Western Montana, Northern California, British Columbia and Alaska.

sentence: The high mountains of the Cascade chain stretch north-south, bisecting the state.

sentence: Despite limited rainfall, agriculture is an extremely important activity in most of eastern Washington, as the soil is very productive and irrigation, supported by dams along the Columbia River, is quite widespread.

sentence: As discussed above, Washington's climate varies considerably from west to east.

name: washington
sentence: A Mediterranean climate predominates in western Washington, and a much drier semi-arid climate prevails east of the Cascade Range.

name: washington
sentence: Major factors that determine Washington's climate include the large semi-permanent high-pressure and low-pressure systems in the northern Pacific Ocean, the continental air masses of North America, and the Olympic and Cascade Mountains.

name: washington
sentence: In the spring and summer, a high-pressure anticyclone system dominates the northern Pacific Ocean, causing a clockwise spiral of air.

name: washington
sentence: For Washington, this means that prevailing northwestern winds bring relatively cool air and a predictable dry season.

name: washington
sentence: In autumn and winter, a system of low-pressure cyclones takes over in the northern Pacific Ocean.

name: washington
sentence: The inward spiral air in the opposite direction of the clockwise makes the prevailing winds of Washington come from the southwest, and brings relatively warm and humid air masses and a predictable wet season.

name: washington
sentence: The term "Pineapple Express" is commonly used to describe atmospheric fluvial events, where repeated storm systems are driven by this persistent cyclone in tropical and near-tropical Pacific regions in the Pacific Northwest.

name: washington
sentence: Although the west of Washington has a marine climate similar to many coastal cities in Europe, there are exceptions such as the "Big Snow" events of 1880, 1881, 1893 and 1916, and the "Deep Freezing" winters of 1883–84, 1915–1916, 1949–1950 and 1955–1956, among others.

name: washington
sentence: During these events, western Washington experienced up to 1.8 metres of snow, subzero temperatures (−18 °C), three months of snow on the ground, and frozen lakes and rivers for weeks.

name: washington
sentence: The lowest officially recorded temperature in Seattle is 0°F (−18°C) set on January 31, 1950, but low-lying areas at about three hours from Seattle recorded lows as cold as −48°F (−44°C).
